text:
DIF now allows individual contributors without being members.  As Rouven pointed out in an earlier email currently DIF members (Associate members) and individuals who signed the Feedback Agreement can participate in the work carried out by the WG.
(please note, Feedback Agreement should be signed by individuals who only represent themselves and they could- and should not represent any of their employers. Preferably only freelancers) 

Please send this form to the folks who already meet the individual contributor requirements <https://bit.ly/DIF-feedback-agreement> and ask them to complete the DocuSign sent after submitting the form. 

Additionally, please connect me with the companies who are not individuals and let me share with them the WG charter and pre-explain them the IPR release etc. related to WG contributions so they can sign the release forms as soon as we figured out the legal aspects, as described below. 
 
Related to your ask and the community's signals we started to look into ways to open up certain Working Groups to allow free company contributions as well. It requires additional legal and accounting work therefore it will take another 1-3 weeks until we can announce the changes. The current goal is to open up WGs for contributing companies for free. At least I can promise that we will make sure that even if not all WGs gets open IDWG will have the same participation arrangement as the Secure Data Storage WG.

attachments.title: DIF - Feedback Agreement
attachments.text: The Feedback Agreement is designed for the Decentralized Identity Foundation to invite individual contributors to DIF Working Groups free of charge. The contributions are provided on an individual level, not as a representative of an organization or company. Here you can see the agreement: <https://drive.google.com/file/d/1HP5JwbPFTfmYIwsxbq1Ye9_h0y_KQhhk/view?usp=sharing> Please fill out this form, and you will receive a personalized DocuSign invite. If there would be any questions, reach out to membership@identity.foundation

Having all of you here I have interesting topic to address and trying to collect some materials,
Security aspect of KERI based identity system. text: <@U035D255M0R> has joined the channel
:wave:

Good Morning Folks-

As we move to harden KERIpy for a production implementation of the vLEI ecosystem, we (mostly Sam) analyzed our approach to rotation events for distributed multisig identifiers.  In particular, our support for partial rotations (rotating with only a subset of all signers that still satisfies the signature threshold) came under scrutiny.

The result was the following issue <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/keripy/issues/144> and subsequent PR addressing the issue.  In short, we changed the format for the `n` field and added an `nt` field for all establishment events to support partial rotations.  The HackMD referenced in this issue has details of the new events and the issue itself details the logic needed to ensure a secure partial rotation.

elements.text:
Good Morning Folks-

As we move to harden KERIpy for a production implementation of the vLEI ecosystem, we (mostly Sam) analyzed our approach to rotation events for distributed multisig identifiers.  In particular, our support for partial rotations (rotating with only a subset of all signers that still satisfies the signature threshold) came under scrutiny.

The result was the following issue
and subsequent PR addressing the issue.  In short, we changed the format for the
n
field and added an
nt

field for all establishment events to support partial rotations.  The HackMD referenced in this issue has details of the new events and the issue itself details the logic needed to ensure a secure partial rotation.

attachments.fallback: <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/keripy/issues/144|#144 New format for next and next threshold in Establishment Events Enables Partial Rotation of all Rotation events>
attachments.text:
The new format for establishment events is defined here  
<https://hackmd.io/Tfm63kdnRdmGxcVgrne5Uw|https://hackmd.io/Tfm63kdnRdmGxcVgrne5Uw>

*Additional validation logic by multi-sig group members prior to signing.*

• Ensure that digest of next public key is included in next digest list, `n` field before signing if the group member expects to be part of the next set of signers. Add a flag to the event signing method to indicate this expectation. A group member may willingly expect to be part of the next set of signers if they are transferring control of the identifier to someone else and would still sign. But if they are expecting to part of the next set of signers and their public key digest does not show up in the next list then it may a surreptitious attempt to wrest control away from them and they should not sign.
• Update UX/UI to display the result of this check prior to signing to allows signer to indicate willingness to sign in spite of no longer being included.

*Additional validation logic for rotation event*

• Ensure that set of signatures satisfies both the previous next threshold `nt` from previous est event and the current key threshold `kt` of current rotation event being validated. Support for partial rotation means that prior `nt` and current `kt` do not have to be the same but must be both satisfiable. Prior `nt` must be satisfied by a subset of the public keys committed to in the prior `n` field list. Current `kt` must be satisfied by a superset composed of the prior `nt` satisfycing set combined with any additional needed public keys from current `k`.

*Multi-sig group membership*

There are two classes of members in a multi-sig group.

A) Member of the current set of signing keys, i.e. public key in `k` field list  
B) Member of the next set of signing keys, i.e. public key in `n` field list

A Member may be in both A and B or in only one of A or B. Membership in B means ultimate authority because only members of B may participate in the next rotation event which may change membership of both A and B. Membership only in A means current signing authority only and no authority to rotate.

In addition a former Member may be thought of as having Alumni status once removed from a multi-sig group but no longer has any authority over the identifier controlled by the multi-sig group

The UX/UI for a given establishment event may want to indicate the group membership status and any proposed change in status prior to approving a new proposed establishment event.
attachments.title: <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/keripy/issues/144|#144 New format for next and next threshold in Establishment Events Enables Partial Rotation of all Rotation events>

<@U024CJMG22J>, here are my next set of questions, prefaced with assumptions:
*Assumptions*:
1)     Provenant platform will create a hosted cloud wallets in AWS for entity’s
2)     Provenant platform will use delegated keys to act on behalf of the holders of the wallets
 
*Questions*:
1)     Since private keys need to be stored in an entity’s (hosted) wallet, should the entity’s inception event happen after the wallet is created and run on the server where the wallet is stored?
2)     Does the Provenant platform, on behalf of an entity, need to supply the AID to the QVI for it to issue a vLEI to the entity?
3)     Who makes the request for a vLEI?
4)     When a QVI issues a vLEI to an entity, how does the entity receive the credential offer?
5)     GLEIF uses a GLEIF delegated key to issue vLEIs to QVIs, does it also give QVIs a GLEIF delegated key or do QVIs use their own private key to sign credentials they issue?
6)     Can a delegated key be created from a delegated key? Who approves the delegated key of a delegated key?
7)     Does a request for a delegated key result in a new AID and pair of keys for the delegatee? If yes, does that mean that the delegatee needs a wallet?
8)     Please confirm that pre-rotated keys and delegated keys are stored in the holder’s wallet in the secure key storage along with the private key
9)     Does an entity with a Validating Agent role need a vLEI? Or does the Validating Agent only vet entities and work with LOUs to issue LEIs?

elements.text: , here are my next set of questions, prefaced with assumptions:
Assumptions

:
1)     Provenant platform will create a hosted cloud wallets in AWS for entity’s
2)     Provenant platform will use delegated keys to act on behalf of the holders of the wallets
Questions

:
1)     Since private keys need to be stored in an entity’s (hosted) wallet, should the entity’s inception event happen after the wallet is created and run on the server where the wallet is stored?
2)     Does the Provenant platform, on behalf of an entity, need to supply the AID to the QVI for it to issue a vLEI to the entity?
3)     Who makes the request for a vLEI?
4)     When a QVI issues a vLEI to an entity, how does the entity receive the credential offer?
5)     GLEIF uses a GLEIF delegated key to issue vLEIs to QVIs, does it also give QVIs a GLEIF delegated key or do QVIs use their own private key to sign credentials they issue?
6)     Can a delegated key be created from a delegated key? Who approves the delegated key of a delegated key?
7)     Does a request for a delegated key result in a new AID and pair of keys for the delegatee? If yes, does that mean that the delegatee needs a wallet?
8)     Please confirm that pre-rotated keys and delegated keys are stored in the holder’s wallet in the secure key storage along with the private key
9)     Does an entity with a Validating Agent role need a vLEI? Or does the Validating Agent only vet entities and work with LOUs to issue LEIs?

text: 10) If a wallet is created before an inception event, how is the wallet associated with an entity? Is it by the friendly name of the wallet?

elements.text: 10) If a wallet is created before an inception event, how is the wallet associated with an entity? Is it by the friendly name of the wallet?

text:
1.  Yes, creation of an identifier occurs after the database and keystore is created.  From the command line tool, you run `kli init` first and `kli incept` afterwards.
2. There are detailed flows for identity assurance and identifier exchange as part of the vLEI ecosystem.  Those need to be followed to ensure secure communication on which the credential issuance is based.
3. There are designated representatives for a Legal Entity who are authorized to request any of the credentials from a QVI
4. There is a credential issuance peer to peer protocol define as a series of `exn` messages.  The holder will receive a `exn` message with a `/credential/issue` route.
5. Private keys are never shared with KERI.  Each QVI will create an identifier that is delegated from the GLEIF External AID.  So the QVI has its own keys for its identifier with is delegated from GLEIF.
6. Yes, a new identifier can specify a key that is also a delegate as its delegator.  So it would look like A -> B -> C  where A is B's delegator and B is C's delegator.  To authorize an establishment event of a delegate, a delegator needs to anchor the establishment event in either an interaction (`ixn`) or a rotation (`rot`) event.   So in B's case, she could authorize C's events with an `ixn` event and not require any further action from A.  But is B wants to use `rot` events to anchor C's events, those events would have to be verified by A with a corresponding anchor.
7. Yes, a delegate needs its own wallet and holds its own keys.  The delegate initiates its own AID, specifying the AID to use as its delegator.
8. All private keys (current and next) are stored in the secure key storage, yes. 
9. Validating Agents are part of LEIs and not vLEIs so they won't need vLEI credentials
10. A wallet is merely the database and keystore.  An identifier created for that wallet has all its key material stored in the keystore and yes, it is given a user friendly name so human's can remember what it is later.

FYI:
```CEN/CLC/JTC19  has approved a  work item aiming to produce a Technical Specification with the following title: "Decentralised Identity Management Model based on Blockchain and other Distributed Ledgers Technologies. –Part 1: Generic Reference Framework".As per document N 103, the scope of the work item is the following: "The proposed standard will specify a reference architecture for decentralised identity management, optionally enabled by distributed ledger technology (DLT) and blockchain systems. The reference architecture aims to natural persons and legal entities and addresses concepts, cross-cutting aspects,   architectural considerations,  and architecture views,  including functional components,  roles, activities, and their relationships with blockchain and DLT.```

text:
Hi Janet, my name is Ruth Choueka, I work with Randy Warshaw. I was wondering if I could possibly ask you questions regarding the wireframes you shared with him? For instance, in the Profile/Contacts/Settings wireframes there are several wireframes for managing aliases. My understanding, from looking at the wireframes, is that an alias can be associated with a default credential, and a profile can have a default alias. Is that right?

What is the purpose of different aliases, does each alias represent a different AID (inception event)?

In the wireframes shown, the *default alias* value is the same as the *name* value, is that always the case?

Regarding the witness URLs, the user has to enter them, he does not have the option of choosing them from a drop down list of possible witnesses?

text:
Hi Ruth,

We're actually working on revising those, so these are great questions! :relaxed:. We're likely going to go with last used over setting a default AID. Each one does represent a different AID. You can name it whatever you want, the name just seems like the more likely option.

Additional tests need to be added for commands not yet tested. The current tests demonstrate how to capture and test again standard output.

Tests for commands that require witnesses could be added using the code from `test_multisig.py` to launch witnesses for tests.

text:
Now that the `keripy` development team has finished the big push to complete the vLEI XBRL Annual Report Signing Pilot (see press release here: <https://www.gleif.org/en/newsroom/press-releases/gleif-showcases-one-digital-id-for-every-business-globally-with-first-verifiable-lei-deployment> ) we are updating the branches and development process to live up to our commitment to have a more stable `main` branch in our repository.

We just renamed our primary branch from `master` to `main` and then created the `development` branch which will be used for all active development moving forward.  Any PRs should be submitted against `development` and we, as a community will agree when it is time to cut a next release from `development` and merge all outstanding changes into `main`.  We will commit to ensuring that all unit tests, demo scripts, command line commands and REST APIs will work as advertised at all times on the `main` branch moving forward.  (There will be a series of PRs over the next week or so to get us there).

If you have already cloned or forked the `keripy` repo, you can run the following commands to update your local copy of the primary branch from `master` to `main`.

```git branch -m master main
git fetch origin
git branch -u origin/main main
git remote set-head origin -a```
Of course changing `origin` to whatever your remote is named for the `WebOfTrust/keripy` remote repository.

text:
<https://github.com/weboftrust/keri/blob/main/docs/Glossary.md#backer>
Hi Lance, for what I’ve understood is that Ledger-registered backers are a secondary root-of-trust at best. It’s an extra guarantee. The primary root of trust is the KEL, which is cryptographically verifiable to this primary root-of-trust (PKI). Afaik KERI doesn’t organize portability between two ledger-registered backers (from one ledger to another), However, KERI is a portable autonomic identifier system in itself by design, and you’re free to use as many blockchains as you like to create secondary roots of trusts. But how efficient or useful that’ll be….
Phil definitely has a better thorough understanding of KERI and all of its technicalities. But this is my take on it, feel free to correct me if I am wrong (because I might well be :slightly_smiling_face: )

text: thank you <@U02PA6UQ6BV>. the glossary is really helpful for reconnecting to these terms, as I get to know them.  we love the root-of-trust model of KERI to enable portable AIDs, for sure! I’m currently thinking through the  ledger as a replacement for the witness network.  if we do that (not just discovery nor hybrid model, like we discussed yesterday), then there will be configuration in the Inception Event of the AID that includes configuration for the ledger backer oracle connection information?  If so, then on rotation i should be able to update my oracle list (similar to updating witnesses, and witness thresholds,etc).  but i’m not certain if the backer configuration is separate from the backer ids and then how the mechanics of changing that during rotation might work.  Hopefully I can address some of my misunderstandings when I talk to Phil about the GLEIF witness network.  looking forward to it!

text:
Interesting, Lance, I’ll follow your efforts. Here again my two cents:
The problem with a ledger being the single root-of-trust for a witness (if I understand your idea correctly) is that its key are not rotatable. You’d need a transaction on the ledger to rotate the controlling key of the witness, which leaves you locked in: not portable anymore (locked to the silo / blockchain of this specific ledger), it’s become algoritmic identifier not an autonomic one. I believe KERI needs AID based witnesses to be able to offer KERI’s
• security model: duplicity detection and reconciliation
• features: portable identifiers, secure attribution over the web

text:
<@U02PA6UQ6BV>: I had a look at your terms wiki. Very impressive work, and I think this will be immensely valuable to the entire community.

I turned on automatic glossary generation for the wiki, and configured it slightly. Here is the URL for the glossary that goes with your terms wiki: <https://trustoverip.github.io/acdc/glossary>

Notice that when you hover over a term, there's an icon at the left that allows you to link to a specific term. When you click the icon, it copies onto your clipboard a link to that term. For example, here's the term "digital signature": <https://trustoverip.github.io/acdc/glossary#digital-signature>

I noticed a few things about the data on the wiki pages that was making the glossary sub-optimal, so I fixed things here and there. Some things you might check if something doesn't render the way you want:

1. Images as displayed in raw wiki markdown have a different canvas size than images in the glossary. For this reason, it is often best to force images to be a specific size that will be good for the glossary. You can see how I've done this in the wiki page for authentic chained data container, for example: <https://trustoverip.github.io/acdc/glossary#authentic-chained-data-container-acdc>

text:
I understand the antipathy. How is Keri being marketed? Marketing is important. I have been a part of some pathetic startups where marketing was non-existent. All of them failed as a result.

There is no getting around the “popularity” of certain concepts whether we like them or not.

attachments.text: The architecture of an identity system has a profound impact on the nature of the relationships it supports. This post categorizes the high-level architecture of identity systems, discusses the properties of each category to understand architectural influences, and explores what their respective architectures mean to their legitimacy as a basis for online life.
attachments.title: The Architecture of Identity Systems

text:
<@U03RLLP2CR5> I do believe that AID repo was a placeholder that we probably don't need any longer.  And yes, the structure of an AID is documented in CESR, but I think someone would be hard pressed to understand that on the surface.  Since CESR is an encoding format that is not specific to KERI, or identity for that matter, a real definition probably doesn't belong there.

Perhaps as <@U024KC347B4> suggested we should add something to the SAID spec that specifically defines an AID.

I think it’s KERI & ACDC related. KERI for secure attribution over the web and ACDC for veracity (based on VCs).
It’d be interesting to see if specific ACDC stuff like correlation prevention and step by step disclosure could be a killer feature for the CAI members.

text: I'll give an over all witness description here and then try to answer specific questions where they were asked.

elements.text: I'll give an over all witness description here and then try to answer specific questions where they were asked.

text:
Each witness is independent and keeps local copies of all KELs that they know about.  We have not implement gossip protocols yet so as an alternative we have implemented the policy that all controllers are responsible for propagating their key events to all their witnesses and then pass out all receipts from each witness to the other witnesses.   In addition, the controller is also responsible for introducing witnesses to each other when a controller uses them together.  This eliminates the need to bootstrap any kind of witness introduction while we don't have gossip implemented.

Gossip is dependent on UDP protocol support which is dependent on CESR streaming of events themselves which Sam has started but not finished because revised rotation rules has taken precedence.   Once we pop that stack and have gossip working, witness (and watcher) communication will be simplified.  But for now, keripy controllers make sure to introduce all witnesses to each other (admittedly a little chatty), sends events to each witness, collect all receipts from each witness and then send them back out to the other witnesses.

elements.text:
Each witness is independent and keeps local copies of all KELs that they know about.  We have not implement gossip protocols yet so as an alternative we have implemented the policy that all controllers are responsible for propagating their key events to all their witnesses and then pass out all receipts from each witness to the other witnesses.   In addition, the controller is also responsible for introducing witnesses to each other when a controller uses them together.  This eliminates the need to bootstrap any kind of witness introduction while we don't have gossip implemented.

Gossip is dependent on UDP protocol support which is dependent on CESR streaming of events themselves which Sam has started but not finished because revised rotation rules has taken precedence.   Once we pop that stack and have gossip working, witness (and watcher) communication will be simplified.  But for now, keripy controllers make sure to introduce all witnesses to each other (admittedly a little chatty), sends events to each witness, collect all receipts from each witness and then send them back out to the other witnesses.

text: As for HTTP vs TCP.  Witnesses do expose a TCP port which will work fine for direct streaming of KERI events.  However, the keripy agent and command line exclusively use CESR streaming over HTTP.

elements.text: As for HTTP vs TCP.  Witnesses do expose a TCP port which will work fine for direct streaming of KERI events.  However, the keripy agent and command line exclusively use CESR streaming over HTTP.

text: The reason is that we had to focus on HTTP in order to support mailboxes for controllers that do not have persistent Internet connection and that was built using HTTP.

elements.text: The reason is that we had to focus on HTTP in order to support mailboxes for controllers that do not have persistent Internet connection and that was built using HTTP.

text: So all the configuration we use currently favors HTTP for all communication

elements.text: So all the configuration we use currently favors HTTP for all communication

text: Yes, the current witness implementation in keripy is promiscuous.  As long as a controller commits to a witness in its KEL, the witness will provide a signed receipt.  It is assumed that any deployment of witnesses will provide authentication over their witnesses to prevent them from witnessing for any AID.

Found a paper <https://koreascience.kr/article/JAKO202101355700154.pdf> discussing this algorithm. There:
```At present,
SM2 is also used in blind signatures, proxy
signatures, threshold cryptosystems and secure
cooperation between two parties. However, no one
has conducted research on SM2's batch verification
algorithm. This article proposes SM2 digital
signatures A batch verification algorithm for the
same signer and different signers.```

text:
Hi all,

I have a couple of questions about credentials

1. Are there plans for supporting querying credentials by attribute value or metadata parameters? For example letting a credential issuer query issued credentials by LEI code or by date of issuance?
2. Semantics of OOR and ECR authorization credentials. Who issues OOR and ECR authorization credentials and who is the recipient? What values will be set in personLegalName, officialRole and engagementContextRole attributes of the authorization credential?
<https://github.com/WebOfTrust/vLEI/blob/b84d69905d3052f80e9ac3e11fafa3ef2a35878b/schema/acdc/ecr-authorization-vlei-credential.json#L66-L73>
<https://github.com/WebOfTrust/vLEI/blob/b84d69905d3052f80e9ac3e11fafa3ef2a35878b/schema/acdc/oor-authorization-vlei-credential.json#L66-L73>
3. Extending credential schema. For example how can I extend ECR credential schema with an email attribute?
4. Credential expiration. The roles that OOR and ECR credentials represent often have a known end date based on some business contract for example. Is there a way to set expiration date on these credentials?

Thanks!

elements.text:
Hi all,

I have a couple of questions about credentials

1. Are there plans for supporting querying credentials by attribute value or metadata parameters? For example letting a credential issuer query issued credentials by LEI code or by date of issuance?
2. Semantics of OOR and ECR authorization credentials. Who issues OOR and ECR authorization credentials and who is the recipient? What values will be set in personLegalName, officialRole and engagementContextRole attributes of the authorization credential?

3. Extending credential schema. For example how can I extend ECR credential schema with an email attribute?
4. Credential expiration. The roles that OOR and ECR credentials represent often have a known end date based on some business contract for example. Is there a way to set expiration date on these credentials?

Thanks!

text:
I want to know these answers as well. Good questions. Here’s my understanding from what the KERI whitepaper and IETF specs say:

1) querying credentials by metadata is supported and querying by value is part of the graduated disclosure mechanism so yes, support exists or is planned for both.

2)looks like VLEI specific credential types. Only a vLEI expert can answer completely. I suspect either a QVI or a company itself issues both of those types. Don’t take my word for it. I imagine the values are context specific. If you are looking for a type system to select from a distinct set of values there may be a specification somewhere that constrains those values. Otherwise the values are up to the issuer.

text:
3) extending the credential schema should be doable by adding another ACDC linked to the original as ACDCs are an extensible graph structure.

4) there’s a way to set the expiration date on any credential since an expiration date is a regular property of a credential. Regardless of an expiration date you will want to verify control authority for a credential by verifying KELs.

text: My understanding is that only a QVI can issue an OOR, but it requires an AUTH credential (<https://github.com/WebOfTrust/vLEI/blob/dev/schema/acdc/oor-authorization-vlei-credential.json>) from the Legal Entity to the QVI; the Legal Entity must hold a valid Legal Entity vLEI credential.

elements.text: My understanding is that only a QVI can issue an OOR, but it requires an AUTH credential (
) from the Legal Entity to the QVI; the Legal Entity must hold a valid Legal Entity vLEI credential.

text: I believe the ECR can be issued by either the Legal Entity or by a QVI if the Legal Entity issues an AUTH credential (<https://github.com/WebOfTrust/vLEI/blob/dev/schema/acdc/ecr-authorization-vlei-credential.json>) to the QVI.  In either case the Legal Entity must hold a valid Legal Entity vLEI credential.

elements.text: I believe the ECR can be issued by either the Legal Entity or by a QVI if the Legal Entity issues an AUTH credential (
) to the QVI.  In either case the Legal Entity must hold a valid Legal Entity vLEI credential.

text:
Yes, the QVI is the only who can issue OOR credentials and the QVI can also issue ECR credentials.
The QVI issued OOR/ECR credentials require OOR/ECR authorization credentials.
I would like to understand the authorization use case.
The OOR/ECR authorization credentials have basically the same attributes as the actual OOR/ECR credentials (personLegalName, officialRole and engagementContextRole).
Is the LE authorizing the QVI to issue OOR/ECR credentials one at a time, where every QVI issued credential requires a separate authorization from the LE?
I would have expected authorization contract to be on more generic level where the LE authorizes a QVI to issue any OOR/ECR credentials.

text: In this morning’s call about making JSON-LD `@context` optional, I thought I heard Sam say that the DID answer was to make it required and that this was a mistake. However, in the VC issue 947 I see comments like <https://github.com/w3c/vc-data-model/issues/947#issuecomment-1284900418|this> that indicate that the resolution was to NOT make it required. Am I misunderstanding?

elements.text: In this morning’s call about making JSON-LD
@context
optional, I thought I heard Sam say that the DID answer was to make it required and that this was a mistake. However, in the VC issue 947 I see comments like
this
that indicate that the resolution was to NOT make it required. Am I misunderstanding?

attachments.fallback: <https://github.com/w3c/vc-data-model/issues/947#issuecomment-1284900418|Comment on #947 Make the usage of `@context` optional>
attachments.text:
I have not had the bandwidth to more fully participate in this WG, however since this particular issue received many months of discussion in the W3C DID WG — where it was ultimately decided that <https://github.com/context|@context> would not be required in the plain JSON representation of a DID document — I wanted to share some of those learnings here.

Although I am not a developer myself, in my discussions over the past few years with developers of various types of "verifiable credentials" (meaning the generic term as defined by the VC 1.0 spec: "A set of one or more <https://www.w3.org/TR/vc-data-model/#dfn-claims|claims> made by an <https://www.w3.org/TR/vc-data-model/#dfn-issuers|issuer> that has authorship that can be cryptographically verified"), the feedback I have gathered is: _while JSON-LD and the RDF graph model is *one* perfectly good solution to decentralized semantic interoperability, it is not the only one_.

What I have seen in the wild is at least three other solutions:

1. *Out-of-band agreement to an external specification.* This might actually be the most widely deployed solution in the wild today, where the semantics of a credential are pre-determined by application context or pre-agreement.
2. *JSON Schema or another well-known schema language.* These have matured a great deal in the last decade.
3. *<https://neo4j.com/blog/rdf-triple-store-vs-labeled-property-graph-difference/|Labeled property graphs.>* I am nowhere near an expert on LPGs — I learned about them from Sam Smith — however I later realized the LPG model is what the OASIS XDI Technical Committee (of which <https://github.com/peacekeeper|@peacekeeper> and I were co-chairs) ended out using for semantic interoperability.

None of these are abstract examples — all in use today. For example, LPGs (expressed using JSON Schema) are the basis for semantic interoperability of the <https://trustoverip.github.io/tswg-acdc-specification/draft-ssmith-acdc.html|ACDC> credential format used by <https://www.gleif.org/en/vlei/introducing-the-verifiable-lei-vlei|GLEIF vLEI credentials> that are on a path to be adopted by over 70 financial services regulators around the world.

My point being: by all means use `@context` when a credential uses a JSON-LD representation. That's the mechanism JSON-LD defines to control semantic validation in its representation of the VC data model.

But if a credential uses a different representation, that representation should define its own mechanism to control semantic validation. I believe that's what <https://github.com/selfissued|@selfissued> meant when he said, "Let JSON be JSON".

For those tracking the `main` branch of keripy, we just pushed all the changes from the latest development branch into main.

The major change for this upgrade was the Neo changes that create stable transformations on CESR.  Also included is work in the Hab and Matter classes towards support for the new revised rotation rules to more fully support custodial key management.  Finally, a bunch of upgrades to the `kli` commands are included.

text:
<!channel> Due to recent activities in keri community and some uncertainties have arisen in regards of the license of Human Colossus Foundation implementation would like to provide you some insights. As you all know HCF have very specific strategy regarding protecting the community and the implementation which we are working  on. We invested already quite some resources and money into what we have build. Our vision could be described as: building with community for the community. Based on that we did quite in deep evaluation of different licensing options and we ended up (in our opinion) with one of the best option which is EUPL1.2. I know that a lot of people do not have a good understanding of that part and sometimes misinterpret the consequences of the license. This is why we prepared short summary of our reasoning and argumentation why we pick EUPL and why it matters for us.
Here you can find it: <https://hackmd.io/@hcf/H1Og-0yUj>

I would love to here everyone take on that and prepare questions if you have any.

As you know as HCF we are working on many components of KERI ecosystem and we are pretty advance in it, including keriox, cesrox and said all that is already separated, and is used in multiple projects. Obviously we don't mind if that work would be duplicated because you would find a good reason to not go with EUPL license. But as far as I know there is no reason to do so. And if someone would be able to prove benefits of other license for those components which fulfills our demands we are willing to change that license for benefits of community. Until that would happen, we would protect our community investment in a way as described above.

I already requested to have a slot on the KERI call to provide some more insights and hear everyone opinion in that regards and eventually address some of those questions. If everything goes right we would have a chance to speak on next KERI Call but before hand feel free to provide your feedback and post questions in this thread.

Best regards
Head of Technology Council at Human Colossus Foundation

text:
Is <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/skwa|SKWA> the best start for building an authentication system and authorization system using KERI?

I am mapping the KERI protocol onto a traditional sign-in and authorization model.
It seems that the sign-in would be replaced with a profile acknowledgment based on a stored credential in some local browser storage that then personalized a user’s experience.

This requires a web wallet or web data satchel (help me name this). Do we have any examples of storing credentials or keypairs in indexeddb? I know it’s not the best solution though I’m just doing a POC prototype.

If there are no examples then it seems all I need to do for a web is the following:
1. The ability to create, store, and recover a keypair, inception and rotation,
2. The ability to send messages to witnesses and store receipts
3. The ability to view stored credentials and 
4. to send existing credentials (graduated disclosure)
5. The ability to issue new credentials
6. The ability to sign events, or respond to signing challenges.
I’m still reading through the SKWA document so maybe it covers many of these points.

text:
<@U013F46SDRR> Thanks the write up and clarifications. I am not sure what ‘activities and uncertainties’ you are referring to, but, I certainly have made numerous references to the license change as a reason keriox ‘exists’ under web of trust, but have always qualified it with “the HCF guys are so awesome, they donated a version before the license change”. purely for clarification of why that repository exists at all.

I’m not sure of other peoples intentions for keriox, but the notion of cesrox came about after the last IIW where CESR was identified as a source of "this is hard to adopt" - so we used the keriox you contributed under the apache2 license to start cesrox (this IIW) we're currently in the process of completing changes for the "neo" changes and subsequently the indexer changes in keripy, I'll push Phil and I's branch - which while incomplete shows progress to being parallel with keripy in terms of cesr.

Something that the upstream keriox impls would want to do as well.

text:
By ‘activities and uncertainties’ I mean that people are not sure how the know-how brought by HCF can be reused and how we can collaborate since we under another license. A lot of people treat EUPL as GPL which leads to wrong assumption.

Yes we (and Jolocom) contributed keriox to weboftrust as the work started on Apache 2 and we didn't wanted just simply pull that from DIF. We decided to switch to EUPL for better protection of the community behind it. What was already done stays under that license we cannot withdraw it or at least won't be nice to try to hid it anyway.

I am fine with two project under different license. We have strong arguments why we chose the EUPL - mainly to protect the community and avoid situation that private company would pick it and extend it without sharing back, causing forks and split of the community or even the protocols. It is beneficial for whole community if we would continue use EUPL. But as I said it is our world view and complete understand if other would take thoughtful decision based on facts and not just false assumption.

We are investing quite a lot into the development of those components and I bet that other community members would like to do that as well. Doing it twice it is just a bit of wast resources especially if there would not be any good argument for that.

Especially that we are almost done with cesrox as a separate package.

text:
<@U013F46SDRR> Thank you for the explanation of EUPL, and especially the link to the full strategy write-up at the Foundation. This helps me with some of my previous reservations, and I see EUPL as a valid approach. I might be willing to support the development under that license.

— though I personally prefer the most-permissive and least-wordy licence. There is space for more permissive licensing. We’ve learned from GPL & LGPL that people will shy away from viral & restrictive licenses which hurts adoption; that doc makes the point that even Google has mistakenly marked this license as unusable … and although it’s a mistake, it is a barrier. Honestly, I think SQLite has done the right thing with <https://github.com/trentlarson/endorser-ch/blob/master/LICENSE|that license>; sure, it may not force the community to contribute back, but it’s clear… and I see the threat to adoption & collaboration (whether by mistake or by malice) as the bigger threat, higher than the threat of someone failing to give back.

But I’m now more willing to follow the group if they want to build on THC code.

that license

; sure, it may not force the community to contribute back, but it’s clear… and I see the threat to adoption & collaboration (whether by mistake or by malice) as the bigger threat, higher than the threat of someone failing to give back.

But I’m now more willing to follow the group if they want to build on THC code.

text:
Completely agree that lengthy and complicated licenses does not help regular users to jump on board. But keep in mind that in many cases licenses like that does not have any grounding in the real law. For individual person maybe that is not very important but when you deal with businesses or governmental services you can't simply skip that bit.
Or define "do good not evil" - good for whom, what means good?. If you face serious business and face their legal department you would bounce of it relatively quickly.
Community needs support to navigate through this space anyway. This is why we team up with lawyers to make sure that we get it right and we are able to protect our community in the right way.  Through our experience we went through many open source communities and initiatives and personal must say that I am feed up with the direction which this takes. "Open Source" become marketing tool, nobody think about collaboration and community, Big tech companies used that to warm up their image. It  lead to a trap called "platforms" and providing free development force for those who actually can monetize specific technology. You use open source and think that your are independent because you have control over code but you are under control of corporate machine. One of many  examples is android as OS which is great open source OS but actually without using google services this operating system is useless and not user friendly, You can NOT have simple push notification in your own "open source" app running on open source service, using open source backend without google having stake in that.

Decentralization is not only about technology it is as well about governance and distribution of power. Letting everyone do what ever they want (more permissive licensing) is not always good for what we do.

text:
A <https://weboftrust.github.io/ietf-keri/draft-ssmith-keri.html#section-10.2|reply> message is the closest kind of event I could find that might serve this purpose. Nothing else jumps out at me yet. It would seem odd that a witness would refuse to witness a controller’s key events given that the controller can select its own witnesses. The following quote from section 10.2 *Indirect Replay Mode* of the white paper illustrates this fact:
> _The reliance on a designated set of witnesses provides several advantages. The first is that the_
> _identifier’s trust basis is not locked to any given witness or set of witnesses but may be transferred_
> _at the controller’s choosing._

elements.text: A
reply

message is the closest kind of event I could find that might serve this purpose. Nothing else jumps out at me yet. It would seem odd that a witness would refuse to witness a controller’s key events given that the controller can select its own witnesses. The following quote from section 10.2

of the white paper illustrates this fact:
The reliance on a designated set of witnesses provides several advantages. The first is that the
identifier’s trust basis is not locked to any given witness or set of witnesses but may be transferred
at the controller’s choosing.

text:
So, given that a controller selects its own witnesses it is the responsibility of the controller to validate the suitability of each witness prior to including that witness in an inception or rotation event as a declared witness.

As a part of the witness evaluation process I could see value in adding a protocol-level event for a given KERI agent (witness, watcher, juror, judge) to indicate it is not able to or will refuse to be a witness for a given controller, though this delves into business-process specific decisions that are likely bespoke to a given implementation and thus don’t yet make sense to add to KERI itself.

text:
thanks <@U03R27M4FM3> I missed the call but watched the recording and I am missing some argumentation on the main point which I believe triggered the idea for GUT, if I may ask  <@U03RLLP2CR5> why you think that there is no proper mindset in place in those communities to be collaborative? Do you have specific examples?

From perspective of HCF (and HCF is part of few of those communities DIF, KERI, ToIP, Aries) we found it very collaborative, and lack of adoption of those specific technologies is more a problem of specific use cases or lack of time to contribute (at least in our view). Not sure how the additional umbrella can help here, wouldn't that be additional overhead?  Happy to learn about what obstacles you encounter to achieve what you presented about GUT.

It reminds me a bit the situation from roughly 3 years ago where we ended up in similar position and we tried to tied governance, identity and data space, to have holistic framework for digital economy and we tried with Aries, DIF and later at ToIP but at the end we found that  each of the community is lead by different needs and was hard to enforce holistic view. This is how HCF was created. So far we where able to unify all above into one stack and linking all technologies created in different place (contributing in those places in the same time) into what you would call GUT. If you didn't I recommend to read introduction to DDE Stack: <https://humancolossus.foundation/blog/dde-launch>

We continue sharing and promoting our achievements in all mentioned communities but we know how hard is to break the ice in a way to think about certain things and hard to enforce it. Based on our experience just following Unix philosophy is more then enough and helps with adoption. This is how we were able to introduce OCA into Aries ecosystem and same way we are building keri components (cesr, sai, tel and more). Happy to hear your experience and understand the reasoning.

text:
I have been tasked with doing presentations to a US government agency (that will remain unnamed) for the purpose of teaching them about the vLEi ecosystem (KERI, CESR, ACDC, etc).  I was given a list of questions to answer, many of which started with "why".  While those "why" questions have been the most interesting to answer (as well as the ones that cost me the most sleep), my favorite question to answer was "How does KERI support cryptographic agility, specifically how could it use new algorithms to provide post-quantum security?"  I believe Falcon was specifically mentioned as part of that question.

Tomorrow morning I will answer that question and with the help of Sam (of course) I was able to create a KERI inception event using Falcon-512 to generate public and next keys and sign the inception event.  I did this using the Open Quantum Safe library (<https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs>) with the python bindings (<https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-python>) integrated into KERIpy.

Here is the inception event (with a hefty public key):

I have been tasked with doing presentations to a US government agency (that will remain unnamed) for the purpose of teaching them about the vLEi ecosystem (KERI, CESR, ACDC, etc).  I was given a list of questions to answer, many of which started with "why".  While those "why" questions have been the most interesting to answer (as well as the ones that cost me the most sleep), my favorite question to answer was "How does KERI support cryptographic agility, specifically how could it use new algorithms to provide post-quantum security?"  I believe Falcon was specifically mentioned as part of that question.

Tomorrow morning I will answer that question and with the help of Sam (of course) I was able to create a KERI inception event using Falcon-512 to generate public and next keys and sign the inception event.  I did this using the Open Quantum Safe library (
) with the python bindings (

) integrated into KERIpy.

text:
One of the "why" questions I have to answer is "why did Sam create something new (CESR) instead of using what we already have (CBOR, COSE, Multi-Codec)?"

The answer is very clear to me now.  We believe that all data in the future will need to be authentic data and therefore, cryptographic primitives (AIDs, key digests, signatures) will be included with every bit of data transmitted and stored across the internet.  Those primitives must be represented as strings and not data structures to ensure we are able to ship the most compact form of those primitives.  CESR is the only encoding format that enables us to ship cryptographic primitives as first class encoded strings that are more compact than CBOR structures of the same data and even more compact when shipped as binary.

text: Phil this is great for me to explain to people to help them understand why all this stuff is so important. This was a point I was missing when I described why we are going in the direction we are. Really appreciate it. It was the same argument, really, when I worked at Certicom. We were into ECC when everyone was using RSA, and additionally our implementations were so optimized for specific platforms that they were able to operate in constrained environments where others weren't. Decentralized identity is going to need to be deployed in a similar fashion, it isn't all laptops and mobile phones.

Last ACDC meeting, near the end, Daniel asked a question and I came up with a potential solution to it by concatenating two identifiers to form a single one. The idea was that a namespace would be hashed to provide the first part of the identifier, and a complete data structure to provide the rest. I’ll now give a complete description that I believe will create an auto-governing system, potentially addressing Phil’s concern. Sorry for not using the typical one letter identifiers, I don’t know them off the top so I’m going to be verbose so that I can communicate clearly.
If we combine (
namespace.digest
digest

), we can create a fixed-length searchable (by digest of issuer and name) versioning system where only the identified issuer can create versions of their data. There is no administration required, I believe. The trick is that
issuer
is an input to
namespace.digest
, and
namespace.digest
is an input to
digest
(we could use a compact expression of this information). The caveats:
to allow this data to enter such a system, one needs it to be signed by the issuer
to prevent abuse, one needs to ensure that one has the ability to throttle/cap by issuer id (unless, I suppose, resources are unconstrained?)
consumers would be pulling
all
versions for a given
name
issuer
pair
Is this new/useful/flawed?

text:
What would prevent another issuer to register the exact same name?  How then would someone tell which is the correct hash?

I feel like namespacing is for human readability to bridge between what a human sees and understanding it’s the correct issuer (for example). So I’m not sure what digesting the namespace buys us here. 

Namespace is a reputation issue and therefore should be resolved by trust anchors, not any central registry.

text:
A small _side step_: Validate, verify, validator en verifier are terms we might have to reiterate now and again. In our domain (KERI/ACDC) we seem to be able to work within the broader eSSIF-lab definitions. Mind you, the _<https://essif-lab.github.io/framework/docs/essifLab-glossary#validate|validate>_ definition is very general, in the KERI/ACDC vocabulary ‘validate’ currently has diverse meanings including this one.

<https://essif-lab.github.io/framework/docs/terms/validate|Validate> (general)
<https://essif-lab.github.io/framework/docs/essifLab-glossary#validate|the act, by or on behalf of a >*<https://essif-lab.github.io/framework/docs/terms/party|party>*, of determining whether or not that data is valid to be used for some specific purpose(s) of that *<https://essif-lab.github.io/framework/docs/terms/party|party>*.

<https://essif-lab.github.io/framework/docs/terms/verify|Verify> (general)
<https://essif-lab.github.io/framework/docs/essifLab-glossary#verify|The act, by or on behalf of a >*<https://essif-lab.github.io/framework/docs/terms/party|party>*, of determining whether that data is *authentic* (i.e. originates from the *<https://essif-lab.github.io/framework/docs/terms/party|party>* that authored it), timely (i.e. has not expired), and conforms to other specifications that apply to its structure.

In the KERI/ACDC domain we have come here:
<https://github.com/trustoverip/acdc/wiki/validator>
<https://github.com/trustoverip/acdc/wiki/verifier>

If your border case / criterium is authenticity, as one could understand from “Validated meaning there is some signed chain going back to a root that validates the issuer as a member”, then first part of the sentence is what a verifier in KERI/ACDC in a narrow sense does, the second part ‘validate as a member’ is more a validator’s role.
Example: You keypass of the hotel might verify, the doorman might still not validate you as a guest allowed inside (validation).

It’s all about what we as a group collectively understand how individual members look at the criteria to draw lines between closely related terms in our terminology, even if borders between certain terms are vague. At the same time it would come in very handy if the outside world, outside of KERI/ACDC would still know what we’re talking about.
“I first have to try to understand what you mean, and then we might enjoy the bliss of reversal.”
I pass the baton back to Phil / Jason.

text:
Right, and that was why I used the word validated - because it wasn't just a verification that was required to ensure participation allowance in the system, and I guess this is what Phil was talking about - that gating of participation makes the system still dependent on some type of business level decision.

I actually take great issue with people saying 'hash' when they mean 'digest'. A hash is a function that produces a digest. They aren't technically the same thing (or never were), but everyone uses them interchangeably.

Folks, I have looked diligently for the recording of the meeting that was held a few weeks ago, wherein the naming conventions in keripy were explained. I was told that it was an ACDC meeting, so I walked through the ToIP wiki. I found all the agendas, but no links to recordings at all. Perhaps I'm just lacking in insider knowledge about how to find ToIP recordings?

I also looked at the keripy and keri repos, hoping to find meeting recording links. I found in the KERI agendas a reference that I think is to this content. It's in meeting notes (captured by <@U024CJMG22J>?) for the KERI meeting on Jan 24 (<https://hackmd.io/-soUScAqQEaSw5MJ71899w#2023-01-24>). The agenda says at the top, "No recording made." Then, three lines below that, it says, "English semantic naming by <@U013SSREL0H> (see recording)". I don't know if this is the meeting that I need, but it sounds like it?

So: does any recording in fact exist?

If not, are there any other materials that I could consume that would help me learn the same concept?

Imo it’s a recurring problem with KERI and ACDC meeting, the availability of *recordings*… Not only at WebOfTrust (KERI) but also at ToIP (ACDC).

I wanted to take the lead in assuring all recordings, both KERI and ACDC are uploaded and linked in their meeting notes and here in Slack only 15 minutes the latest, after a meeting has taken place. This is what I strive for and _it’s really needed_ to serve newcomers, people that want to educate themselves and people that have missed a meeting.
To make a long story short: I stopped asking for / begging for recordings or access so I currently can’t do it.

text:
Sorry if this is the wrong channel, but I have a question about KERI messages, and specifically the interpretation of the `kt` (key signing threshold) field. In some instances, the value of this field is a list of strings (representing fractionally weighted thresholds), and in others, it is a string, representing an P-of-Q condition, where P is the integer value in the field and Q is the length of the `k` (list of signing keys) field. In terms of an interpretation of these two different value types, would it be correct to assert the following equivalence?

`"kt": "N"`  is the same as `"kt": [ "1/N", "1/N", ... ]` where `len(kt) == len(k)`  and for all `0 <= i < len(kt)` , `kt[i] == "1/N"`

text: Yes, a single number threshold that is less than the total number of keys is a simpler expression of an equivalent  fractionally weighted threshold.

text: <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/keri#meetings>

KERI is a protocol developed by Dr Sam Smith, keripy is the reference implementation of that protocol.

There is a white paper and draft IETF specification along with it.

CESR, ACDC, PTEL, SAID are all derivatives that have been extracted from, or developed from the original white paper by Sam or <@U024CJMG22J> primarily, it’s open source so obviously there are other contributions.

There is no one over arching organization, that’s the great thing, we get contributions from a variety of companies.

<@U04HQD29Z7E> has a good point, there was a split over the introduction of a European copy left license for a variety of reasons.

Sams original idea was to use IETF to harbor specifications and Apache2 to foster implementations.

His reasoning he documented in the WebOfTrust/keri readme I believe.

Welcome! Hopefully we can answer any questions you have.

text:
We have started from scratch with cesr/parside, the short version is: CESR is a sub spec of keri and is often deemed the “hard bit” to implement making adoption harder.

We decided to start from scratch and model closer to keripy (which fully implements cesr) than what was previously out there.

As Sam continues to develop cesr, keripy will likely remain the spearhead of development, libraries downstream (in my opinion) will benefit from being closer to keripy (harboring a common vernacular etc)

cesride is designed to be purely the primitives required for cesr, that might not be what you want right off the bat. Parside will consume cesride and represent the parsing module of keripy

text:
We touched on that topic multiple times during various community calls, long story short you can't get better then that, means KERI architecture fits perfectly into that space (as many others) if you think about accuracy of information or even simply device management in divers ecosystem DKMS beats anything which you can compare with. Why because it is agnostic to the ecosystem means you can do it simple in centralized highly controlled ecosystem but as well implement it in highly divers and decentralized/federated as well.
There are different technical solutions which can be applied depending on the use case based on that approach. IoT space is so vast that hard to just simply give short pros/cons. Since you didn't brought any specific "KERI vs xyz" or "KERI for zyx" I can share that it fits extremely well, and we start seeing some commercial adoption in that space at scale (really big scale and very sensitive). If you are interested in more details I will be presenting that topic on Identity Week in Amsterdam (June 14th)  (I have few limited VIP tickets to distribute for that event, those who will prove they are worthy :wink: happy to share). We also provide consulting services where we can roll out in details pros and cons tailored for interested use case.

P.S. decentralized IAM based on blockchain is not decentralized - I don't think that needs to be explained in that group :wink:
and if you want to compare it to DID, very high level description can be found here: <https://humancolossus.foundation/blog/thinking-of-did-keri-on>
DIDs are not secure (with few exception) this is why KERI come to existence to solve that problem.

text:
I am reading the KERI white paper and came across the fact that KEL is considered a secondary root of trust (Page 60/141, Section 7.35).

In my understanding (which seems to be wrong), the controller of a transferrable AID—where the inception key is already rotated—needs both the current signing key and a KEL to cryptographically prove their control authority over the AID. Hence, my previous understanding was that the AID together with its KEL acts collectively as the primary root of trust.

I would really appreciate it if someone is willing to clarify this point.

elements.text:
I am reading the KERI white paper and came across the fact that KEL is considered a secondary root of trust (Page 60/141, Section 7.35).

In my understanding (which seems to be wrong), the controller of a transferrable AID—where the inception key is already rotated—needs both the current signing key and a KEL to cryptographically prove their control authority over the AID. Hence, my previous understanding was that the AID together with its KEL acts collectively as the primary root of trust.

I would really appreciate it if someone is willing to clarify this point.

text:
It is important to remember that KERI's security is based on the layering of thresholds.  The whole is greater than the sum of it's parts.

So while it seems that with a transferable identifier (one that can be rotated), the security of the identifier starts with its KEL, it does not.

As with all identifier types (transferable and non-transferable), the security starts with entropy.  The randomness used to create the private key is the absolute root of trust.  Once you create the private key you retain the ability to prove control over your identifier by your ability to use the private key.

With non-transferable identifiers, it ends there.  With transferable identifiers, the next root of trust (and thus a secondary root of trust) is the KEL which provides the ability to rotate the keys of the identifier.

Additional roots-of-trust layered on top of entropy and KELs include multi-sig support, delegation and witnesses.

text: In every cryptographic system entropy rules, and if you don't use a good rng (a csprng) you're boned from the start. This is really important for everyone in the space to understand. I knew a guy who was really into measuring hamming weights of outputs for everything he did as a crude way of ensuring sufficient entropy in the things he built.

text: I mostly used random generators that came from main crypto libraries. How can we know if there are good or not. Is there a list of libraries that we should consider using in out projects, or a list of the ones that we should never use?

elements.text: I mostly used random generators that came from main crypto libraries. How can we know if there are good or not. Is there a list of libraries that we should consider using in out projects, or a list of the ones that we should never use?

text:
Generally you want to use the one supplied by the operating system. In linux this used to be `/dev/urandom` I believe but there was another one that wasn't cryptographic (the tradeoff must be speed, I've never read about it though I have implemented a prng or two).

In Rust you typically use `OsRng` from the random crate in fashion. In `cesride` we rely on two variants due to the expectations of `ed25519-dalek` and `k256`, and we simply pass them to the libraries to generate keys. You'd need to investigate how to get random bits in whatever language you are using, and just make sure what you are reading is about a `csprng` and not just an `rng` or `prng`.

This looks like it has a lot of good info, though I'm a bit lazy about reading it today:
<https://crypto.stackexchange.com/questions/11345/definition-of-a-csprng>

text: And, even a good `csprng` should be seeded well - if you can get random data from measuring user input or environmental conditions that can't be easily controlled you will generally be more resistant to attack. Think about the case for example, where a designer is tempted to use a radio receiver and noise to seed the RNG, but an attacker floods the space with a frequency that produces a deterministic result in the ADC or something.

text:
Here's a way to view entropy on the command line (should work in Linux and macOS):
```cat /dev/urandom | od -tx1 -Ax```
if you want a specific number of bytes, something like:
```dd if=/dev/urandom bs=1 count=32 > entropy
cat entropy | od -tx1 -Ax```

text:
In KERIpy we use libsodium through the python bindings.  I've never actually looked at what their documentation says about randomness, but here it is:

>  The library provides a set of functions to generate unpredictable data, suitable for creating secret keys.
> • On Windows systems, the `RtlGenRandom()` function is used.
> • On OpenBSD and Bitrig, the `arc4random()` function is used.
> • On recent FreeBSD and Linux kernels, the `getrandom` system call is used.
> • On other Unices, the `/dev/urandom` device is used.
Thought that was interesting based on this conversation.

text:
Yesterday I presented to the Aries WG the did:keri method as an alternative to did:peer. You can find the recording at the end of this <https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/ARIES/2023-02-22+Aries+Working+Group+Call|meeting notes> (that recording, starting at min 21:20,  can be also  useful for those who weren’t at the KERI meeting when I presented the topic  weeks ago since it was not recorded).
The Aries WG has now the task to compare different candidates: did:peer:1, did:peer:2, did:keri, did:legacypeer and make a recomendation. Quote with what they are looking to compare:
```- Verifying and document that the transformation can be made in each case — e.g. from unqualified DID and related DIDDoc to the new format — and what extra information and libraries would have to be defined/used for each.
- Create a spreadsheet of the properties that we get from each so that we have a comparison — size of DID, key rotation, ease of transformation, future path, multi-key support etc. Some will be subjective, but I think we have them in one place, it might be easier to see the differences.```

text:
I have a polite request I'd like to make.

Our little KERI World community is growing, over the past couple of years we've incorporated a lot of new projects, CESR, ACDC, the entire vLEI ecosystem. We've seen production deployments and proof of concepts, we've done (more than I can count) presentations, we've had people attend conferences and represent this community. We're writing specifications and pushing for recognized standards for the work this community does.

However, KERI World (this Slack) and the Web Of Trust repositories are not a traditional standards organization, there's no paid infrastructure. There are no full time people who support it, it is literally a community of volunteers working together under a banner of like-mindedness.

This Slack is not Stack Overflow for KERI, we can't scale to that, there just is not enough of us.

My polite request is this, introduce yourself.

Introduce the work you're doing (so we can be excited about it with you!), if you haven't been to a KERI/ACDC/CESR call, do so, it's great to put faces to names and it is how our community grows closer and stronger together.

attachments.text: ABSTRACT: Cryptographic agility was once seen as a desirable goal for computer security, but increasingly problems such as high costs, bad interactions, and downgrade attacks show the flaws of the methodology. We need to thoughtfully adopt alternatives such as cipher suites, methods, or just careful layering, to make sure that the new wave of digital identity and asset projects being released now doesn’t repeat the mistakes of the past.
attachments.title: Musings of a Trust Architect: Problems of Cryptographic Agility

text:
Clarification by Christopher that we got: “GLEIF appears to be adopting many of the design patterns of JOSE, which is an example of the perils of cryptographic agility.”

Are we on the same page, or are we mixing up LEI and vLEI?

elements.text:
Clarification by Christopher that we got: “GLEIF appears to be adopting many of the design patterns of JOSE, which is an example of the perils of cryptographic agility.”

Are we on the same page, or are we mixing up LEI and vLEI?

text:
I believe he's simply referring to the fact that various cryptographic primitives can be used. Such as various hash methods or signatures.

The danger of cryptographic agility is simply that libraries can be poorly implemented and not follow proper verification logic. Which was famously the case with JOSE/JWTs ( e.g. headers are <https://auth0.com/blog/critical-vulnerabilities-in-json-web-token-libraries/|malleable> ). Another gotcha is that people will use poor choices when configuring keys, selecting algorithms, etc.  That's what `nacl` is helping to avoid. Or `paseto` tokens, etc.

Lastly, it adds complexity  to the processing logic and therefore potential bugs, including side channels. See TLS crypto suits ( e.g. downgrade attacks).

From my standpoint ( and I'm not a cryptographer) KERI is using cryptographic agility justifiably:
• new type or stronger key algos can be used in the future for transferable prefixes. 
• the set of primitives is relatively small and is easy to reason about.

text: I think Vasily is correct here.  He is confusing KERI's support of cryptographic agility, which means support for multiple algorithms with the problems JOSE had because they allowed flexibility is selection of parameters for specific algorithms.  The later allowed for downgrading security by making poor choices in the parameters.

text:
<@U024CJMG22J> so my (personal) reply to Chris about his remark “GLEIF appears to be adopting many of the design patterns of JOSE, which is an example of the perils of cryptographic agility.” could be:

According to the KERI/CESR/ACDC team behind the GLEIF vLEI implementation you might be confusing KERI’s support of cryptographic agility, which means support for multiple algorithms. The current KERI suite uses relatively dumb but seasoned cryptography.
The problems JOSE had because they allowed flexibility is selection of parameters for specific algorithms. The latter allowed for downgrading security by making poor choices in the parameters. This is not the case at GLEIF nor in the KERI stack.

text: The issue with the way it is defined now, as I see it, is that they use raw public keys rather than KERI identifiers which was probably done for simplicity. There is nothing saying KERI couldn't back this kind of system, and in fact if everyone was using non-transferable keys many things probably simplify, but the user wouldn't be able to retain control of their account in the case of compromise. If instead, a message was tagged with an identifier, the solution becomes more complex but users can recover and protect their account.

text:
Imagine these two scenarios to start:

1. You want to purchase a bottle of wine and need to prove your age, but your driver's license contains all kinds of information you'd rather not share with the staff. Instead of giving them an id, you scan a QR code on their device and begin OOBI with the seller, and begin an exchange process of graduated and selective disclosure that ensure that if you have a credential or ACDC with appropriate chain of authority (back to something like a governmental body) proving you are 19, proof of this and your authentic, unexpired id photo is presented for verification by the employee via the exchange. Their system allows them to approve the sale, and you haven't disclosed your address etc.
2. You are arriving at the hospital and dread filling out forms. No need! With ACDCs issued via KERI and their associated records, proven authentic and signed by doctors and institutions, you can enter the hospital without filling any kind of forms.
These are the two examples that unlocked the most new use cases in my mind for decentralized id in general. There are so many more.

Their system allows them to approve the sale, and you haven't disclosed your address etc.

You are arriving at the hospital and dread filling out forms. No need! With ACDCs issued via KERI and their associated records, proven authentic and signed by doctors and institutions, you can enter the hospital without filling any kind of forms.

text:
Those are great examples. I have thought of many more scenarios as well. It’s roughly starting to take shape.

The way you described the “Alcoholic Beverage Age Proof” made it sound a little like the OpenID/OAuth workflow — where interacting with a third party consists of:
#1) Choose an Identity Provider you want to use for interaction.
#2) Sign-in to chosen Identity Provider.
#3) “Review and Accept”, or “Review and Select” what data that will be exposed to the third party.

Whereas, the KERI SSI flow would be something like:
#1) Choose the KERI SSI option as an Identity Provider (no need to sign in, because your keys will be used). Then, if I have never completed the “Alcoholic Beverage Age Proof” with this vendor, I must:
#2) Choose an “Age Disclosure” from a list of acceptable options for providing my age.
#3) Choose a “Photo Disclosure” from a list of acceptable options for providing my photo.

Where, for each disclosure, the third party has pre-selected the “list of acceptable” providers for their specific trust/reputation tolerance level.

Also, the first time you do this, your choices are saved (as an ACDC?), so the next time these disclosures are presented, you will not need to select them again. And the process will end with #1, making for a better user experience.

Additionally, any other third party that requires an “Age Disclosure” or “Photo Disclosure” and accepts the providers chosen will automatically resolve. Again, resulting in a better user experience.

At least, that is what I would imagine.

#3) Choose a “Photo Disclosure” from a list of acceptable options for providing my photo.

Where, for each disclosure, the third party has pre-selected the “list of acceptable” providers for their specific trust/reputation tolerance level.

Also, the first time you do this, your choices are saved (as an ACDC?), so the next time these disclosures are presented, you will not need to select them again. And the process will end with #1, making for a better user experience.

Additionally, any other third party that requires an “Age Disclosure” or “Photo Disclosure” and accepts the providers chosen will automatically resolve. Again, resulting in a better user experience.

At least, that is what I would imagine.

text: I have an anecdote: If I recall correctly, in a EFWG meeting when I first entered the space I asked Daniel directly if the DWN solution had provisions in it for the strong binding between identifier and keys that KERI allows by virtue of the identifier being a commitment to/derivation of inception. He replied 'KERI is a witness network! It's not the same thing. Of course we have cryptographically bound our keys to our identifiers.' I didn't understand at the time what DID methods were, etc, but I am quite sure he totally missed what I was asking, as he didn't provide any analysis, reasoning, or explanation that educated me. To the best of my knowledge the criticism is unfounded but I am not the right person to comment.

Those are great examples. I have thought of many more scenarios as well. It’s roughly starting to take shape.

The way you described the “Alcoholic Beverage Age Proof” made it sound a little like the OpenID/OAuth workflow — where interacting with a third party consists of:
#1) Choose an Identity Provider you want to use for interaction.
#2) Sign-in to chosen Identity Provider.
#3) “Review and Accept”, or “Review and Select” what data that will be exposed to the third party.

Whereas, the KERI SSI flow would be something like:
#1) Choose the KERI SSI option as an Identity Provider (no need to sign in, because your keys will be used). Then, if I have never completed the “Alcoholic Beverage Age Proof” with this vendor, I must:
#2) Choose an “Age Disclosure” from a list of acceptable options for providing my age.
#3) Choose a “Photo Disclosure” from a list of acceptable options for providing my photo.

Where, for each disclosure, the third party has pre-selected the “list of acceptable” providers for their specific trust/reputation tolerance level.

Also, the first time you do this, your choices are saved (as an ACDC?), so the next time these disclosures are presented, you will not need to select them again. And the process will end with #1, making for a better user experience.

Additionally, any other third party that requires an “Age Disclosure” or “Photo Disclosure” and accepts the providers chosen will automatically resolve. Again, resulting in a better user experience.

At least, that is what I would imagine.

attachments.text:
In mathematics, particularly graph theory, and computer science, a directed acyclic graph (DAG) is a directed graph with no directed cycles. That is, it consists of vertices and edges (also called arcs), with each edge directed from one vertex to another, such that following those directions will never form a closed loop. A directed graph is a DAG if and only if it can be topologically ordered, by arranging the vertices as a linear ordering that is consistent with all edge directions. DAGs have numerous scientific and computational applications, ranging from biology (evolution, family trees, epidemiology) to information science (citation networks) to computation (scheduling).
Directed acyclic graphs are sometimes instead called acyclic directed graphs or acyclic digraphs.
attachments.title: Directed acyclic graph

And once we thought of that, we have been wondering if we would just want to WASM in Signifide instead of writing any client code in TS.  Something we plan on talking about next week.

text:
I want to improve and simplify the process of agents discovering each other so connecting across KERI agents can be intuitive from a UX perspective for non-techies.
I am trying to simplify the user experience of connecting KERI Agents to one another and in so doing am looking to automate as much as possible. I want to understand conceptually why I can’t replace the manual OOBI and challenge phrase sharing with a step that is performed by some matchmaking or discovery server.

Essentially I’d like to have a mobile app have a listing of agents pre-loaded so that the user can just tap an agent to connect with, initiate an OOBI exchange, and then a challenge phrase workflow.
What security guarantees do I lose if I have a man-in-the middle matchmaking or discovery service facilitate this? Do I open myself up to man in the middle attacks or is everything still reasonably secure since OOBI resolution results in key state verification, which cannot be faked?
