text:
I was recommended to read this article at IIW. It seems there is a disagreement on whether to include specific did methods in the spec. One of the motivations that makes me adopt KERI is to avoid this mess entirely and just use AIDs.
<https://blog.joeandrieu.com/2023/04/12/fighting-for-consensus-at-the-w3c/|https://blog.joeandrieu.com/2023/04/12/fighting-for-consensus-at-the-w3c/>

“Summary of Technical Objection

Having the DID WG standardize specific DID methods creates moral hazards that will inevitably reduce the decentralization of DIDs themselves. Whichever methods the group chooses will attain unprecedented acceleration and impact. It will take an increased attention from the WG focused on those methods, taking away from attention that could go to advance all DID methods. That attention will also increase the WGs familiarity with how chosen methods solve certain problems and those approaches will necessarily already have the blessing of the WG, making them preferred favorites over approaches used by other methods. In short, giving the DID WG the permission to focus its attention on selected favorites would directly undermine its ability to advance the work with equal respect for all methods.”

text: The tricky part about those messages was getting the issuance VC TEL event, and then figuring out the order. The trick to the ordering is that you highlight the `d` field in an editor and search for it, and ensure that the first occurrence is when it is the said of the top level entity. So essentially, go through the top level messages and for each `d` attribute near the beginning, do a search and make sure that one is #1.

text: As far as I could tell that only exports the ACDC, not the supporting KEL and TELs required to verify. I guess what I am saying is, if we could package up everything needed to verify an acdc, and then make chaining automagic and build a long, presequenced list of required messages to verify the last acdc in the chain (and the couple events that follow it), it would be great. I am going to build out that functionality for Qui, so I'll take a stab at adding it to the `kli` if you want.

attachments.text:
Sometimes (when developing another implementation for instance - when validating correctness) it would be useful to be able to put data directly in a db. Likewise, it would be useful to pull this data from a db.

Consider this scriptable example (assumes `-i` has been implemented for `vc export`):

```
kli vc export -n first_name -s [SAID] -i > input
cat input | kli ingest -n second_name
kli vc export -n second_name -s [SAID] -i > output
diff -u input output
```

which could be extended to perform integration testing for other implementations:

```
custom_implementation dump [SAID] > input
cat input | kli ingest -n second_name
kli vc export -n second_name -s [SAID] -i > output
diff -u input output
```

The idea is that input would look something like an unpretty version of this data (with signatures), at a minimum:

text: Do we know if there have been any third party security evaluations of KERI? I had an associate ask me this question yesterday.

text: Another question, do we know if or whether Estonia solved the key rotation problem in XROADs or any succeeding system? And if they did solve key rotation, how did they do it?

text:
I have a client asking me for a list of companies that currently use KERI. I gave the following list.

1. GLEIF (first in the world)
2. Provenant (telecom)
3. Qui Identity (going live in about five weeks with non-custodial mobile wallets)
4. The Human Colossus Foundation in the EU. They have many different clients all using KERI and ACDC.
5. RootsID with a Cardano blockchain integration
Who else should be on that list?

text:
As discussed on today's KERI call, here is an initial PR for a schema for credentials of this type. I'd love further discussion.

<https://github.com/WebOfTrust/schema/pull/3>

elements.text: As discussed on today's KERI call, here is an initial PR for a schema for credentials of this type. I'd love further discussion.

attachments.fallback: #3 first cut at an IRL credential schema
attachments.text:
See this preso for background: <https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/17_QEAt5SIBOrKbZdkPW0K8XYNGyA4Fn8Tg-h0kvJTCE/edit#slide=id.g23b7aa762ab_0_225|https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/17_QEAt5SIBOrKbZdkPW0K8XYNGyA4Fn8Tg-h0kvJTCE/edit#slide=id.g23b7aa762ab_0_225>

This is not ready to merge, because:

1. I'm not sure we should merge it without having a sample cred to go with the schema.
2. I think maybe each schema should also have a .md file explaining its use? Not sure how to arrange files.
3. Right now the schema doesn't have any rules (should express gov fw rules) or edges (could be used to represent "I was introduced to X by Y"). Probably needs fixing.

text: <https://wiki.trustoverip.org/display/HOME/ACDC+Meeting+Page>

When someone identifies himself with an ID card, some devices check if the card is fake.  Shouldn't it be worth adding to the schema an option to add "the credibility of the certificate was checked by device X"?  Allows adding a choice of guarantee level of reliability.

elements.text: When someone identifies himself with an ID card, some devices check if the card is fake.  Shouldn't it be worth adding to the schema an option to add "the credibility of the certificate was checked by device X"?  Allows adding a choice of guarantee level of reliability.

text: <@U02MD0HA7EJ>: it's not clear to me what certificate you are referencing. Are you saying that the credential we issue should have a field that records one or more device checks of that very credential?

elements.text: : it's not clear to me what certificate you are referencing. Are you saying that the credential we issue should have a field that records one or more device checks of that very credential?

text:
I meant, apart from the person who checked the person's identity face to face against a passport for example, an optional field *validation machine*, where the name is written and the type of machine X checked the passport itself as not fake (which allows confirmation that the passport itself with which the person identified himself is not fake)

Certificate refers to a passport or any official ID of a person

elements.text:
I meant, apart from the person who checked the person's identity face to face against a passport for example, an optional field *validation machine*, where the name is written and the type of machine X checked the passport itself as not fake (which allows confirmation that the passport itself with which the person identified himself is not fake)

Certificate refers to a passport or any official ID of a person

text: The field is relevant, in case the entity you are identifying yourself to is not satisfied with the confirmation of your face-to-face identification by a third party, but also wishes to verify that the third party has checked your physical ID by a machine that checks for forgery

text: I decided to rename these credentials to "face-to-face credentials" as "IRL credentials" is too dependent on a geeky English acronym. "Face to face" translates into other languages easily, where IRL doesn't.

text:
<@U02MD0HA7EJ>: I have pondered your comments for a couple weeks now, but haven't yet become comfortable with the idea. The reason is that I feel that it encourages a confusion about the purpose of the credentials. But maybe I'm still misunderstanding your vision.

I wrote a markdown file that clarfies the vision/purpose/use cases of the credentials a bit. See /face-to-face/index.md (<https://github.com/WebOfTrust/schema/blob/fdf204882a66de1e2babb8d9ee490b557c23c559/face-to-face/index.md>)

I think the field you're imagining might be called something like `machineCheck?`? You described its relevance by referencing a face-to-face identification and imagined that the issuer has checked the issuee's physical ID. However, I don't imagine that an issuer does any identity checking at all before issuing this credential. That's because the purpose of an IRL credential has little to do with identification. The credential is supposed to prove that the issuee is a human, NOT to prove the human issuee's identity.

I did put an optional field in the schema (`knownAs`) that would allow the issuer to say, "here's a name that I use to interact with the issuee" -- but if it's used, the issuer is not claiming that the name is legally correct or that it's an identifier others should trust or use -- only that it's something they themselves use. So if Alice and Bob meet at a conference, and Alice issues Bob an IRL credential, she could say that the issuee is `knownAs` "BobTheIncredible" to her, because that's what his nametag said -- but she wouldn't care at all whether that was his legal name or just a nickname he felt like scribbling on a nametag. The vital thing she has to check is that the party receiving this credential is a human.

I also put an optional field in the schema for `confirmedHandles` . This is supposed to list email addresses or social media handles that the issuer has used to communicate with the issuee. Perhaps this overlaps a little bit with identification, clouding the purpose of the credential? However, if someone is a work colleague, and knows perfectly well a co-worker's github handle, it seems convenient to let them say so. Like `knownAs`, this is not making a claim about legal identity; if someone's Twitter handle is @bobTheIncredible, it still doesn't mean that's his name.

There is a final way that the current fields in the schema seem to overlap with what you are imagining, and perhaps this is the one that we should explore further. It is the `basis`field. This field intends to give a verifier some idea how deep the issuer's knowledge is of the issuee. So an issuer that says the basis of their credential is "family" is saying they've known the issuee intimately for years; "colleague" is another fairly strong but slightly different basis; "acquaintance" is the basis that Alice should assert for Bob when she meets him at a conference.

I listed in example values for this field the values "nist-ial2". This would be a basis where someone would have to compare a person's live face to a credential like a passport. So if that basis is claimed, a `machineCheck` *might* make sense. However, I'm still not sure it's optimal, because if a person actually used a machine to check the validity of a passport, I suspect that the person who did this was working for an institution that requires NIST-IAL2 vetting. Thus, the issuer should be an institution rather than a person. That would make this a different credential type -- not person-to-person, but institution-to-person.

What are your thoughts?

attachments.text:
*Face-to-Face (f2f) Credentials*
*Purpose*

These credentials document an assertion by one human being, that they have interacted with another human being, face-to-face, in "real" (non-digital, non-remote) life. An individual face-to-face credential provides moderate assurance (with a documented, specific basis) that the issuee is not an AI, an org, or an IoT device. See <https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/17_QEAt5SIBOrKbZdkPW0K8XYNGyA4Fn8Tg-h0kvJTCE/edit?usp=sharing|this slidedeck> for background.

<visual.png|suggested face-to-face visual>  
  
Suggested visual: <face-to-face-visual.svg|svg> | <face-to-face-visual-128.png|128 px> | <face-to-face-visual-64.png|64 px>

Face-to-face credentials prove a party's humanness, NOT their identity. They do NOT replace high-assurance credentials such as passports, drivers licenses, or KYC, because they don't make strong claims about most of the legally definitive attributes of the issuees.

It is possible for Alice to work with Bob for years, and to issue Bob a face-to-face credential on that basis (`knownAs = "Bob", basis = "colleague"`), but to not know that Bob's legal name is actually Roberto. It is also possible for Bob to thoroughly deceive Alice about his name. Neither of these issues invalidates Alice's claim that the party she knows as Bob (whatever his legal identity might be) is a human being rather than a piece of technology or a faceless organization. _That_ is what a face-to-face credential asserts -- and until we have <https://futuretechenthusiast.com/10-most-realistic-humanoid-robots/|more realistic androids>, it is something Alice can decide easily, in even a brief face-to-face interaction.

Knowledge about the existence of real-life humans is generated all the time, with virtually no effort, as we go about our ordinary lives. Thus, face-to-face credentials tap into a source of trust that is cheap, common, and neglected by heavier-weight mechanisms. Importantly, this knowledge is not dependent on institutions; face-to-face credentials democratize and decentralize trust on their focus question, and they limit <https://medium.com/@daniel-hardman/big-desks-and-little-people-e1b1b9e92d79|"big desk and little people" power imbalances>.

Face-to-face credentials might be used to tell the difference between true and fake reports of a news event (since bots claiming to have witnessed the fake events should have trouble proving their humanness). They might be used as a replacement for a CAPTCHA. They might be a requirement for the issuance of other credentials that are intended to be held only by humans.

As with any credential, the trust that a verifier places in an individual face-to-face credential MUST depend on what they know about the issuer (`i` field). Trust SHOULD also be influenced by the data that the issuer offers about the nature and duration of the IRL interaction they had with the issuee (`basis` field). Multiple face-to-face credentials from issuers that are widely separated in time, kind, and public reputation are much harder to manipulate. Since high-assurance face-to-face interactions are common (work or school colleagues we've known for years, family and close friends), we hope that people give and get face-to-face credentials regularly, thus creating a web that provides pretty good assurance of humanness in many contexts.

*Privacy*

Face-to-face credentials allow (but do not require) the issuer to assert the name (`knownAs` field) and/or handles (`confirmedHandles` field) that they have _personally_ used to interact with the issuee. They also allow (but do not require) the issuer to endorse the hash of biometrics (e.g., a photo or voice print) that they agree characterized the issuee as they observed them in real life interactions (`biometricHashes` field). The issuee can carry the actual biometric data and present it to verifiers, thus allowing a verifier to confirm that they are interacting with the same human that the issuer knew.

Issuing and later disclosing this information are both optional. Face-to-face credentials support contractually protected and graduated disclosure. Best practice for privacy would be to disclose no more than is strictly required.

By design, face-to-face credentials do not protect the privacy of the issuer. This means they should be issued by a public persona of the issuer, not a highly private one. Issuers and issuees should carefully consider the tradeoff between assurance and privacy that's associated with disclosing the nature of their face-to-face interactions in a face-to-face credential's `basis` field.

*Governance Framework*

These credentials are governed by rules to enhance assurance, discourage abuse, and keep use cases crisp. The current rules are stated in <rules.json|rules.json> and are identified by SAID `EE1ycWdqBAE_4F-WsXZM83CrjpyCClYgPeINk104bLKX`. New governance frameworks can be written that modify these rules, but each credential MUST reference its associated rules using a SAID or a similar pointer to immutable content. The act of issuing or receiving a face-to-face credential constitutes binding acceptance of the rules.

text:
Thank <@U03RLLP2CR5> for clarifying, if I understand correctly, the goal here is not to "officially" identify who the person is, but to recognize that this is a human being.

I read through the file you wrote.
You mentioned in the goal section that the goal is to recognize that it is a person and not an AI bot for example.

If I understand correctly, the schema has two optional purposes
1. To imitate a face-to-face meeting where connections between people are created by friends bringing friends, thereby creating new connections and trust.
2. Give a scheme to "identification companies" to fill in information about a real, living person.
And I'm trying to figure out the solution. I mean, who is the solution for?
If this is case 2, why do we need a separate scheme? These are companies whose business is identification, which means they probably already have a scheme that describes a human being. One or two optional fields can be added to indicate that the person has been identified as a living person.
If case 1
How is the problem solved?
The average person has two levels of reputation.
The first level consists of dozens of social connections that you can trust directly
The second level is the reputation a person creates for himself in the general public through social networks or any other public publication.
If I understand correctly, the solution is intended for applications that want to prevent a non-human entity from registering as a user several times, otherwise, what does it matter if he is a human or a bot?
So the first level is less relevant because it is very limited in scale. This is because the identifier issuer does not have enough reputation for an application to rely on.
On a second level, we transfer enormous power to famous people, whom we can apparently trust if they saw someone they really see (they protect their reputation and do not make money from creating an identity).
And even then, one person can contact hundreds of celebrities and create hundreds of identities for himself. The question is, what is the difference between him and a bot? Except for the limited duplicate quantity
A third case I saw in the presentation in the link you posted was a community.
I understand that the reference here is to the community that knows each other and wants to rely on facial recognition to add members to the community. What is the purpose of identification? Prevent a talking bot that wastes community time with fake conversations? In this case, doesn't it make more sense to send a personal invitation to those interested in joining?
It may be that I don't understand the scheme's intention or what solution it is intended for. But I would appreciate an explanation.

text: I don't think the purpose should contemplate your use case 2 (identification companies) at all. That's because the credential must be issued by a person, not an institution. Identification companies never issue credentials as *individuals*; they issue as *institutions*.

text:
> If case 1... If I understand correctly, the solution is intended for applications that want to prevent a non-human entity from registering as a user several times, otherwise, what does it matter if he is a human or a bot?
This doesn't prevent Sybil attacks, because one person could hold many of these credentials, and register once with each of them. Rather, this prevents an AI or a device from registering AT ALL, and is agnostic about whether a person should be able to register more than once.

But your language presupposes that the verifier of the credential will be an org that needs to register users, and that kind of hides the main use case in my mind: *what if the verifier is an ordinary human?* There might not be any "registration." What if Alice wants to have a private chat with a person she met on the internet, but she wants to make sure it's not a bot? What if an author wants people to give feedback on the draft of his new novel, but only if they are real human beings? (Almost EVERYTHING in SSI right now ignores ordinary people as verifiers. I wrote about this problem here: <https://medium.com/@daniel-hardman/big-desks-and-little-people-e1b1b9e92d79>)

text:
How about this:

RUN off the CRUD.

RUN stands for Read , Update,  Nullify. Why is it preferred ('run off') over the CRUD (Create, Update, Delete)?

Consider the need to protect 'authentic data' in a decentralized environment.

In a decentralized control model, the data always originates from a controller (aka client). The data created (sourced) by the controller follows the principle of 'Non-Interactive Replay Monotonicity' to be able to protect the data from a replay (events are changed) or a deletion (some events are deleted) attacks. That is to say, the data (or events comprising it) is never deleted, it's rather always added to via updates. Each update, therefore, forms a verifiable, continuous log ( e.g. by providing growing sequence number, date timestamp, etc for each update).  To enable invalidation of data, a special update, called Nullify, is used.

The client, therefore, updates the server (it's peer or peers), which just maintains the log following certain rules (see BADA - Best Available Data Acceptance).

To summarise, the server can only Read the log, add Updates to it, including Nullifying ones. So no Create or Delete.

text:
Hey everyone,

Today, I sent a personal letter to a specific group of KERI suite developers who came just after the leading group (Sam, Philip, and Kevin). If I mistakenly included or excluded you from this group, please let me know so I can correct any errors.

The reason we are targeting this group is because they are the primary audience for our Edu site. We believe it has great potential to provide immense value to developers who possess technical skills and fundamental knowledge in cryptography, SSI, and autonomic identifier systems.

In the letter (scroll back in the Edu channel), as well as in this announcement, we want to update you on the progress of our site, the “KERI suite search engine (KERISSE): Personal learning environment and consensus building with others.” Your input as developers is crucial in shaping the design and functionality of KERI/ACDC and the KERI suite search engine (<https://weboftrust.github.io/WOT-terms/?level=3|KERISSE>).

Our goal is to achieve consensus on the meaning of terms within the KERI suite, with a high level of understanding (minimum output level 7, explanation <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/WOT-terms#levels-of-understanding|here>).
We aim to provide a trustworthy resource-scraping process, a glossary service, sharing of search results, exploration of historical concepts and choices, and enhanced visibility and questioning of code structure.

Your thoughts and suggestions are invaluable in shaping the KERI suite search engine. Mind you, it’s targeted at KERI developers “second batch”, so please be one or think like one :wink: .

You can provide feedback directly or in the HackMD document <https://hackmd.io/2C8ch1meS6ad3F3g2aEewg?both#%E2%80%9CDon%E2%80%99t-make-me-think%E2%80%9D|linked here, section "don't make me think">. We eagerly await your insights and appreciate your contributions to this exciting project.

Best regards, Henk

text:
What is a good way to illustrate the need for watcher networks, verification nodes in KERI? I had more difficulty than expected explaining why, to an engineer, the watcher network is needed.

I explained that, according to the duplicity game, Alice can lie to Bob about what she said unless she tells Cedric the same things (KELs and KERLs) that she told to Bob. Yet the engineer struggled with the concept because Bob can still cryptographically verify everything Alice tells him.

If Alice says two different things over two different points in time then is it always provable duplicity? If so, then can’t Bob just choose to trust the first version of events that he sees and ignore all others? Or is that not good in the case where Alice was hacked and the hacker published events with her signing keys before she rotated to new ones?

Essentially, how do we describe the value of watcher networks? I thought I had this memorized though it turns out I stumbled more than I thought I would. I get it though I am not yet good at explaining this to people. If you know of a place in the whitepaper or any presentations then please point me to them and I will go review those materials. I need to be able to clearly and succinctly justify to members of my engineering team the architectural necessity of watcher networks.

elements.text:
What is a good way to illustrate the need for watcher networks, verification nodes in KERI? I had more difficulty than expected explaining why, to an engineer, the watcher network is needed.

I explained that, according to the duplicity game, Alice can lie to Bob about what she said unless she tells Cedric the same things (KELs and KERLs) that she told to Bob. Yet the engineer struggled with the concept because Bob can still cryptographically verify everything Alice tells him.

If Alice says two different things over two different points in time then is it always provable duplicity? If so, then can’t Bob just choose to trust the first version of events that he sees and ignore all others? Or is that not good in the case where Alice was hacked and the hacker published events with her signing keys before she rotated to new ones?

Essentially, how do we describe the value of watcher networks? I thought I had this memorized though it turns out I stumbled more than I thought I would. I get it though I am not yet good at explaining this to people. If you know of a place in the whitepaper or any presentations then please point me to them and I will go review those materials. I need to be able to clearly and succinctly justify to members of my engineering team the architectural necessity of watcher networks.

text:
Here is my mental model for KERI watchers, which may not be accurate.

I would like to separate two cases: (1) controllers are typical end users and (2) controllers are organizations that issue credentials.

For end users, watchers are probably unnecessary most of the time. Alice can send a KEL to Bob and another inconsistent KEL to Cedric without causing any problems. Duplicity would arise only in the case where Bob and Cedric need to exchange their data about Alice. In this scenario, either Bob or Cedric may set up watchers to monitor Alice’s witnesses.

For organizations, they may issue a lot of credentials (ACDCs) to many people, organizations, or even to the public (as untargeted ACDCs). In this case, I believe it is necessary to set up watchers.

elements.text:
Here is my mental model for KERI watchers, which may not be accurate.

I would like to separate two cases: (1) controllers are typical end users and (2) controllers are organizations that issue credentials.

For end users, watchers are probably unnecessary most of the time. Alice can send a KEL to Bob and another inconsistent KEL to Cedric without causing any problems. Duplicity would arise only in the case where Bob and Cedric need to exchange their data about Alice. In this scenario, either Bob or Cedric may set up watchers to monitor Alice’s witnesses.

For organizations, they may issue a lot of credentials (ACDCs) to many people, organizations, or even to the public (as untargeted ACDCs). In this case, I believe it is necessary to set up watchers.

text:
I can give an extreme example where a government is behaving duplicitously. In this case, the government’s witnesses are designed to promulgate different KELs to different groups of people.

Let’s say the president of that country issues an (untargeted) ACDC and makes it available to half of its citizens using one version of its KEL. Then, the president uses another version of its KEL that is inconsistent with the previous one to issue another ACDC that is made available to the other half of its citizens.

Without watchers, the citizens might not be able to detect that two inconsistent KELs have been used. The government may also repudiate one of its ACDCs at a later time.

If watchers are available, on the other hand, the citizens will be able to tell immediately that the government is doing something fishy.

text:
I believe the witness KA2CE protocol is only useful when the controller is honest, and some of the witnesses (that are fewer than the BFT threshold) are compromised. 

If the controller is malicious, or the witnesses are compromised above the threshold, then watchers are needed to detect duplicity.

text: Hmm. Controllers publish their witness sets ( OOBI). Each witness maintains a hash linked, witness and controller signed "micro ledger" (aka KEL). Assuming that witnesses are not compromised ( RUN and not CRUD) the duplicity originates from the controller ( it signs all the events in the chain, collects and distributes the witness receipts). In other words, Alice would need to construct completely different versions of the KEL and get its set of witnesses to re-write the history for duplicity to reach the public. If Alice, on the other hand, publishes different sets of witnesses ( not via rotation - it retains history)  then it means that there are two version of the Alice's identity in the wild. But these two versions are consistent ( because of the write only KELs).

Assuming that witnesses are not compromised ( RUN and not CRUD) the duplicity originates from the controller ( it signs all the events in the chain, collects and distributes the witness receipts). In other words, Alice would need to construct completely different versions of the KEL and get its set of witnesses to re-write the history for duplicity to reach the public. If Alice, on the other hand, publishes different sets of witnesses ( not via rotation - it retains history)  then it means that there are two version of the Alice's identity in the wild. But these two versions are consistent ( because of the write only KELs).

text:
Watchers can be used to both detect rewritten history (compromised or incorrect witnesses) and verify identity's messages and ACDCs.
Any agent that has to deal with KERI identities ( same as prefixes) has to maintain a local copy of the identity's KEL and watch out for rotation ( rot + drt) and interaction (ixn) events in order to maintain the latest set of keys, backers ( aka witnesses) sets, anchors for delegated identities and TELs.

While doing so, watcher must obtain the logs on periodic basis and compare them against the stored and verified KEL ( first time obtained via OOBI). Store the difference. Due to chaining ( sn + p, p being said of the prev event) any attempt to rewrite history will be detected. At this poin, a watcher can poll other witnesses in the set and thus detect "lying" witnesses or determine that prefix is not trust worthy ( assuming the first OOBI check was performed agains all witnesses).

Furthermore, one can use "first seen replay couples" ( sn + timestamp) to determine the moment in time when the attempts to rewrite history started.

Any agent that has to deal with KERI identities ( same as prefixes) has to maintain a local copy of the identity's KEL and watch out for rotation ( rot + drt) and interaction (ixn) events in order to maintain the latest set of keys, backers ( aka witnesses) sets, anchors for delegated identities and TELs.

While doing so, watcher must obtain the logs on periodic basis and compare them against the stored and verified KEL ( first time obtained via OOBI). Store the difference. Due to chaining ( sn + p, p being said of the prev event) any attempt to rewrite history will be detected. At this poin, a watcher can poll other witnesses in the set and thus detect "lying" witnesses or determine that prefix is not trust worthy ( assuming the first OOBI check was performed agains all witnesses).

Furthermore, one can use "first seen replay couples" ( sn + timestamp) to determine the moment in time when the attempts to rewrite history started.

text:
I really like the goal of leveraging “trust that is cheap, common, and neglected by heavier-weight mechanisms”

It seems the hardest part of this credential schema is agreeing on the schema. Adding biometric hashes and confirmed handles, as well as  the “basis” field and “caveats” seems too complicated to get started. Great roadmap features, yet so much optionality there, and difficult to constrain without knowing how to limit it well.

I suggest starting with only four attributes. knownAs, minutes, dt (timestamp), and a very constrained “basis” field so that it is easy to use and hard to confuse.

Since the goal is to establish personhood then online handles aren’t really necessary or can be condensed into the knownAs field as a separate credential for each online handle. why not use a multiplicity of credentials? Or just link them as separate credentials in a graph to the base personhood credential?

You could maybe even simplify it to three, known as, minutes, and dt, and then have basis be a separate credential as shown in the following diagram.

text: With the faceToFaceCredential as the root for a given interaction between two people you can then layer in additional facts as they become relevant to a given relationship. Then, when that relationship is shared with another person, then they can consume as many additional bases or handles as they require to reach a trust assurance level they are comfortable with.

elements.text: With the faceToFaceCredential as the root for a given interaction between two people you can then layer in additional facts as they become relevant to a given relationship. Then, when that relationship is shared with another person, then they can consume as many additional bases or handles as they require to reach a trust assurance level they are comfortable with.

text: Having multiple bases for the relationship allows it to evolve over time, from a simple name into something more as the story unfolds.

elements.text: Having multiple bases for the relationship allows it to evolve over time, from a simple name into something more as the story unfolds.

text:
I know it could seem silly to say the original model was too complicated and to then suggest a rather complicated looking credential graph.

The way I see it each individual credential should be simple, representing a specific kind of interaction. You combine many small credentials to make a credential graph of something overall that is larger. This allows you to have fine grained expression of each part of the reputation while keeping each individual action simple and quick.

the multisig feature you're looking for, internally employs public keys for signing keys and their digests for rotation keys. You don't need to create any additional identifier, because in the end the multisig feature relies on solely one identifier that just has several members (public keys) and associated thresholds. Actually thanks to recent changes to the protocol, you can establish `personal` , as you call it, identifier, and i.e., two rotations later join more public keys (more devices) into it, making it a group in essence.

If you do not mind, I have some dumb questions due to my lack of understanding of how metadata works in typical opaquely-structured-data.

• When an opaquely-structured-data file is saidified, is its metadata also hashed along with its content?  — I suppose it is a yes.
• When the SAID is embedded in the filename “q2financials-E2948372a9b9019.docx”, if the filename is changed to, e.g., “report-E2948372a9b9019.docx”, is the SAID still valid? — My understanding is that the SAID must be recomputed if the filename is changed.

*Transaction Event Logs / Public VC Registry*
*Introduction*

The _Transaction Event Log_ (TEL) is a hash linked data structure of transactions that can be used to track state. A  
_Public Verifiable Credential Registry_ can be represented in several TELs to establish issuance or revocation state of  
a Verifiable Credential (VC). The KEL is used to establish control authority over the keys used to commit to the events  
of the TEL and sign the VC. The events of the TEL are used to establish the issuance or revocation state of the VCs  
issued by the controller of the identifier represented by the KEL. This document specifies a design for _public_  
VCs only. The use of a hash digest of the VC contents as the identifier of that VC or an attribute in a TEL event allows  
for correlation of uses of the VC.

*Transaction Event Log*

A KERI KEL can control a TEL by anchoring the TEL to key events of the KEL with the following:

1. Create the inception event for the TEL with the TEL specific unique identifier.
2. Generate a hash digest of the serialized content of the TEL inception event.
3. Attach anchoring seals from the KEL events to the TEL events they are authorizing.
4. Sign the KEL event as usual to commit to the digest of the serialized TEL event.

Any validator can cryptographically verify the authoritative state by validating the signatures of the referenced KEL.  
The TEL events do not have to be signed as the commitment to the event is in the form of the digest in the seal in the  
anchoring KEL event and the signatures on that event. Like KEL events, all TEL events have the fields `i`, `s`, and  
`t`. However, the `s` or sequence number field in TEL events represents the "clock" for that transaction set. Each  
transaction set can have its own "clock" (e.g. bitcoin block height, wall clock, etc) and is independent of the sequence  
number of the KEL events. In the case of the Verifiable Credential Registry, the `s` field is simply a monotonically  
increasing integer.

The events are anchored back to the KEL using Event Source Seals whose JSON representation is as follows.

```
{
 "s": "3",
 "d": "ELvaU6Z-i0d8JJR2nmwyYAZAoTNZH3UfSVPzhzS6b5CM"
}
```

For TEL events, this seal back to the KEL will be delivered as an attachment of event source seal triples in duple of  
(s, d).

```
-GAB
0AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAw
ELvaU6Z-i0d8JJR2nmwyYAZAoTNZH3UfSVPzhzS6b5CM
```

Event source seal attachment example (line feeds added for readability)

*Verifiable Credential Registry*

A _Public Verifiable Credential Registry_ (Registry) is a form of a _Verifiable Data Registry_ that tracks the  
issuance/revocation state of credentials issued by the controller of the KEL. Two types of TELs will be used for this  
purpose. The first type of TEL is the management TEL and will signal the creation of the Registry and track the list of  
Registrars that will act as Backers for the individual TELs for each VC. The second type of TEL is the VC TEL which will  
track the issued or revoked state of each VC and will contain a reference to it's corresponding management TEL.

The following events will be used to create and maintain the TELs for the Registry.

*Management TEL*

The state tracked by the Management TEL will be the list of Registrar identifiers that serve as backers for each TEL  
under its provenance. This list of Registrars can be rotated with events specific to this type of TEL. In this way,  
Registrar lists are analogous to Backer lists in KERI KELs. Additional metadata can be tracked in this TEL, for example  
references to Schema. The Management TEL will have two events: `vcp` for Registry inception and `vrt`  
for rotation of the list or Registrars. The events will reference the controlling identifier in the `ii` field and be  
anchored to the KEL with an event seal triple attachment.

The Registry specific identifier will be self-addressing (see <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/keripy/blob/c3a6fc455b5fac194aa9c264e48ea2c52328d4c5/ref/tel.md#self-addressing-Identifiers|below>  
for definition) using its inception data for its derivation. This requires a commitment to the anchor in the controlling  
KEL and necessitates the event location seal be included in the event. The derived identifier is then set in the `i`  
field of the events in the management TEL.

Though it is possible for a given identifier KEL to issue multiple types of credentials, it is anticipated that there  
will be relatively few (usually one) Management TELs anchored to a given KEL. A more scalable approach to issuing  
multiple credential types from a single identifier would be to use delegated identifiers for the different types of  
credentials to be issued.

*Configuration*

The simplest (and most common) case for Registries relies on the witnesses of the controlling KEL and their receipts of  
the KEL events instead of Registry specific backers. To accommodate this case, the `c` element is added to the  
management TEL inception event with the configuration option `NB` to specify that the Registry will never have backers  
configured in the management TEL. In this case, there will only be one event in the management TEL for this Registry and  
the simple events `iss`  
and `rev` will be used for "simple issue" and "simple revoke" respectively in the VC specific TELs. For these events,  
the `ri` field will be the simple identifier referencing the management TEL.

*Registry Inception Event*

```
{
 "v" : "KERI10JSON00016d_",
 "d" : "EOMBBz0AKgL1-n9OK5DAIQLM6Z1FHE35YGFUuveYiM1A",
 "i" : "ELh3eYC2W_Su1izlvm0xxw01n3XK8bdV2Zb09IqlXB7A",
 "ii": "EJJR2nmwyYAfSVPzhzS6b5CMZAoTNZH3ULvaU6Z-i0d8",
 "s" : "0",
 "t" : "vcp",
 "b" : ["BbIg_3-11d3PYxSInLN-Q9_T2axD6kkXd3XRgbGZTm6s"],
 "c" : [],
 "a" : {
     "d": "EEBp64Aw2rsjdJpAR0e2qCq3jX7q7gLld3LjAwZgaLXU"
  },
 "n" : "AAd7Zfk6072acq_37bw29qiHOkG3-vErjQGdtjPRmVE_"
}-GAB0AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAABwEOWdT7a7fZwRz0jiZ0DJxZEM3vsNbLDPEUk-ODnif3O0
```

Registry inception event for establishing the list of Backers

```
{
 "v" : "KERI10JSON00010a_",
 "d" : "EJwVS89RBfBNhX6PpAmpsssMSZDMW68FaYmEOSw8EFP6",
 "i" : "ELh3eYC2W_Su1izlvm0xxw01n3XK8bdV2Zb09IqlXB7A",
 "ii": "EJJR2nmwyYAfSVPzhzS6b5CMZAoTNZH3ULvaU6Z-i0d8",
 "s" : "0",
 "t" : "vcp",
 "b" : [],
 "c" : ["NB"],
 "n" : "AAd7Zfk6072acq_37bw29qiHOkG3-vErjQGdtjPRmVE_"
}-GAB0AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAABwEOWdT7a7fZwRz0jiZ0DJxZEM3vsNbLDPEUk-ODnif3O0
```

Registry inception event for "backer-less" configuration

*Registry Rotation Event*

```
{
 "v" : "KERI10JSON000130_",
 "d" : "EL0dsWLeW88h1yruLnEC5_7TT4jIKRiCZjssVRWAQRTz",
 "i" : "ELh3eYC2W_Su1izlvm0xxw01n3XK8bdV2Zb09IqlXB7A",
 "p" : "EY2L3ycqK9645aEeQKP941xojSiuiHsw4Y6yTW-PmsBg",
 "s" : "1",
 "t" : "vrt",
 "ba" : ["BXhpfP_H41hw8f-LluTidLfXxmC4EPwaENHI6CuruE6g"],
 "br" : ["BbIg_3-11d3PYxSInLN-Q9_T2axD6kkXd3XRgbGZTm6s"]
}-GAB0AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACQEOWdT7a7fZwRz0jiZ0DJxZEM3vsNbLDPEUk-ODnif3O0
```

Registrar rotation event updates the list of Backers

*Verifiable Credential TELs*

The binary state (issued or revoked) of each verifiable credential (VC) will be tracked in individual TELs associated  
with each VC. The state changes will be represented by 4 sets of 2 events: `iss` for simple VC issuance and `rev`  
for simple revocation, `bis` for the issuance of the VCs with backers and `brv` for revocation of the VCs with backers  
and corresponding events `iis`, `irv` and `ibs`, `ibr` to be used when the identifier of the VC is not the  
self-addressing identifier of the VC and that identifier must be included is the separate `vi` field in the event. The  
events will be anchored to the KEL with an event seal triple attachment signified by the grouping counter `-e##`.

*Self Addressing Identifiers*

The advantage of a content addressable identifier is that it is cryptographically bound to the contents. It provides a  
secure root-of-trust. Any cryptographic commitment to a content addressable identifier is functionally equivalent (given  
comparable cryptographic stren…

* * *

*tags: KERI, IETF, Community*
*KERI Community Meeting Agenda*

<https://hackmd.io/-soUScAqQEaSw5MJ71899w|hackmd-github-sync-badge>

Chair: Samuel M. Smith <sam@prosapien.com|email>  
Co-Chair: Philip Feairheller <pfeairheller@gmail.com|email>

Meeting Bi-weekly starting on 2021-10-19 at 10 am EDT

Agenda: <https://hackmd.io/-soUScAqQEaSw5MJ71899w|https://hackmd.io/-soUScAqQEaSw5MJ71899w> (linked from <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/keri/blob/main/agenda.md|github> but edited in HackMD)

Zoom Meeting:  
<https://us02web.zoom.us/j/89842900185?pwd=OEpXSU5pa29FR1A3OXFkUithZFNwQT09|https://us02web.zoom.us/j/89842900185?pwd=OEpXSU5pa29FR1A3OXFkUithZFNwQT09>  
Meeting ID: 898 4290 0185  
Passcode: 300255

Calendar Invite:  
<https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/tZ0lc-uhrjsrEtFmV2aSfAzR015DDL-ld-hg/ics?icsToken=98tyKuGhpj8oE9SVsRGCRpx5Go-ga_PziGJcj7d7kSm3AhNVQxnEZrMXFpZTXdTU|https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/tZ0lc-uhrjsrEtFmV2aSfAzR015DDL-ld-hg/ics?icsToken=98tyKuGhpj8oE9SVsRGCRpx5Go-ga_PziGJcj7d7kSm3AhNVQxnEZrMXFpZTXdTU>

KERI Slack: <http://keriworld.slack.com|keriworld.slack.com>  
<https://join.slack.com/t/keriworld/shared_invite/zt-14326yxue-p7P~GEmAZ65luGSZvbgFAQ|https://join.slack.com/t/keriworld/shared_invite/zt-14326yxue-p7P~GEmAZ65luGSZvbgFAQ>

Explanation of KERI development tools and techniques: <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/keri/blob/main/docs/keri-dev-env.md|KERI development environment>

*Meetings*
*Future Topics*

• keri-lite options trade-offs
• More discussions for Witnesses and Watchers. Gossip protocol, UDP, ecosystem configuration.
• Direct Mode Agents
• Custodial Agents
• Demo of how to write tests for KeriPy
• How could we use KERI/ACDC to attest to definitions in the Education material
• Does anything in the Keri/ACDC world replace DNS? If not entirely, does it replace any aspect of DNS
• KERI Lite
    • Sam: Service endpoint bound to DID, so we can't change the endpoint without changing the DID.

*ToDo*

• Future extract Keep library to NPM library
• Cardarno as Ledger Registrar
• github actions for releases
    • including docker containers
• Creating webdriver (or selenium) tests for generic features of Keep.
• Docker Container with port for ReST API
• Split out keripy core from keripy Rest API

*Weekly Agendas*
*2023-07-25*

• Recording
    
    • TBD
• *Announcements*
• Reports
    
    • KERIpy
    • KERIsse
    • KERIA
    • SignifyPy
    • SignifyTS
    • CESRide
• Discussions
    
    • did:webs developments, collaborations and papers
    • Migration from kli to KERIA via multisig rotation
    • Agents and Mailboxes replacing Witnesses (no, not like that).
    • Move to ToIP meeting schedule and "location" (Zoom)

*2023-07-11*

• Recording
    
    • TBD
• Announcements
    
    • Change the source of glossary from ToIP back to WebOfTrust. The source of truth will be WoT, but can be sync'ed back to ToIP.
    • GLEIF successful demo PoC vLEI with regulatory body.
    • Looking to demo issuance of ACDCs to IIW participants
• Reports
    
    • KERIpy
        
        • Updating state notifications for key state and transaction state, from KERI events to plain SADs.
        • Added to dev multi-sig rotation kli support future new member of group push to dev.
        • Main 1.01 no breaking
    • KERIsse
        
        • Adapted KERIsse to have new source of truth.
        • Updated the "How we did it" documentation.
        • Implementing TypeSense search engine, scraping related sites including GitHub repositories.
        • Automation of source material clean-up to remove problematic characters.
        • Adding Levels across individual paragraphs and articles.
    • KERIA
        
        • Changes: addition of advanced searching for credentials in wallet. Help issuers to show issued credentials. create indices using SAD path language with pagaination. Using CESRSuber for indices
        • Several fixes to address bugs in credential issuance and presentation
    • SignifyPy
        
        • Few updates to integration script.
        • issue-ecr.sh shell script
    • SignifyTS
        
        • Working on credential issuance and credential issuance with witnesses
        • Updates to fix challenge response APIs
        • Upcoming: revocation and credential querying API support
        • Fixes to support running from Node
    • CESRide
        
        • Tests against the WASM stuff added earlier this year
        • Aiming to move CESR primitives(sp?) from CESRide into Signify-TS
• Discussions
    
    • Moving the specifications to ToIP and impact of that on meeting structure
        
        • In the process of moving the specifications for the protocols in support of ACDCs into ToIP
            • We originally wanted to move everything to ToIP when we left DIF but that was blocked.
            • Code repos will stay at WebOfTrust, just the spec text.
        • For meetings, do we want to continue with this WoT meeting or fold into the ToIP meeting?
            • Suggestion to have a rolling format across meetings based on what the group wants to talk about
            • Membership required to contribute to the meetings - Membership for individuals is free for ToIP
        • The current charter for ACDC in ToIP already includes reference to all the supporting protocols.
            • All specifications would be moved including, KERI, CESR, SAID, PTEL, OOBI, etc.
        • Combining the meetings will make it less confusing for newcombers to only have to join ToIP and find one meeting.
        • Change the focus of the meeting to the KERI/ACDC stack and let the community decide.
        • How should this effect Slack?
            • Keeping KERIWorld or merging everything into ToIP Slack.
            • Argument to keep KERIWorld because that is where source code is coming from and where those discussions should remain because the ToIP charter specifically states that no source code is being delivered
        • Need to be aware of stropiness in the processes of ToIP and user management.
        • Resolution to combine the meetings into the existing ToIP meeting passed.
            • No changes until we get specifications moved, an announcement will be made.
    • Question regarding credential search API
        
        • GET vs POST for search API?
            • GET is "RESTy" but the parameters are overly expressive and results in long URL
            • POST is not RESTy
            • For now we are putting parameters in BODY of GET.
            • Open for suggestions.

*2023-06-27*

• Recording
    
    • TBD
• Announcements
    
    • IEEE P7012 standard effort formalize graduated disclosure for terms and conditions Doc Searls
        • Machine Readable Privacy Terms "Riccardian Contracts"
• Reports
    
    • KERIpy
        
        • Continuing port to new Serder object versioning of protocol and packet types
    • KERIA (keri agent)
        
        • PoC of Credential Issuance integration with signifypy signifyts
        • route normalization http resources
        • cueing system
        • google spreadsheet
    • SignifyPY
        
        • minor updates to align with route normalizion
    • SignifyTS
        
        • some updates to match KERIA start implement credential issuance
    • Cesride
        
        • Implementing selective disclosure with compacting exn
        • SealsSourceTriples Anchors to another KEL prefix sn said,
    • KERIsse
        
        KERI Suite Search Engine  
        (KERISSE) report:
        
        1. We* now have shareable links into the search engine pop-up; example: <https://weboftrust.github.io/WOT-terms/visualisations/?Wot-terms%5Bquery%5D=ixn&searchModalStatus=open|ixn>
        2. First repo scraped and indexed: Weboftrust-keripy. You can filter on repos in the left menu.
            
            We have new <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/WOT-terms/discussions/30|responses> to what KERISSE should mean to the community, thanks to our respondents!

text:
How can I pay for a Slack channel setup by someone else?

ChatGPT
The payment for a Slack workspace (a collection of channels, direct messages, and the people who belong to them) is typically managed by the workspace owner or an admin. If you want to pay for a Slack workspace that was set up by someone else, here are some general steps you could follow:
1. Contact the Workspace Owner/Admin: Reach out to the workspace owner or an admin to express your intention. They can change billing responsibilities if they agree.
2. Change Billing Ownership: If the current workspace owner or admin agrees, they can transfer ownership to you. This can be done through the workspace settings. Remember, this gives you control over the entire workspace, not just the payment, so it’s a significant responsibility.
3. Add a New Payment Method: Once you’re the billing owner, you can add a new payment method. Go to 
4. S`ettings & administration`
5.  > `Billing` > `Payment method`.
6. Update the Payment Information: Enter your payment information and make sure it’s set as the default. You will then be billed for the workspace subscription.
Remember, it’s important to discuss these changes with the current workspace owner/admin and other relevant parties to ensure everyone is comfortable with the change. If you’re paying on behalf of a company, it’s also essential to make sure this complies with any relevant policies or procedures your company may have.
Please note that this information is based on Slack’s policies and procedures as of September 2021, so it may have changed. Be sure to check Slack’s current documentation or contact their support for the most accurate and up-to-date information.

text:
Hey everyone, for the next little while I have an hr (ish) daily to start contributing toward a JS/TS library if there's agreement that it's a positive contribution to make at this time. Given the right support in terms of understanding the spec and implementation I'm willing to put some time and effort here.

As a start I began exploring possibility of strong compile-time typings for some of the primitives like identifiers. I quickly ran into TS limitations. For example it's possible to type for a 44 character base64 SAID but it fails with depth of recursion for 512 (88 char) identifiers. We could use Opaque types but it's a bit hacky with TS and you make some downstream trade-off.

I wonder if it makes more sense to expose types best we can for consuming devs via JSDoc / TS definitions while leveraging a validation library like Joi for runtime checks instead of trying to have strict types at the library level. This would also make development more productive imo.

Would love some thoughts on the above. Would also love to have someone to help orient me toward action assuming again that a TS/JS lib is a productive use of effort at this time.

text: There are several precursors that are required to start that.  First, a choice would have to be made whether to start with the TS native implementations of the CESR primitives or the Rust versions from CESRide via WASM.  Second, if TS is selected, those primitives would have to be extracted from Signify-TS into a CESR-TS library so they could be made available to both Signify-TS and KERI-TS.  Finally, decisions regarding private key storage would have to be made which seems like a pretty significant can of worms that we haven't considered it yet.

text:
Zulipchat

Pros

• Open source
• Can be self-hosted
• Topic based threading allow for efficient management of information
• No need to sign in to view the messages (easier access for potential new community members)
• Free for open source projects
Cons

• The interface might be new to some people

Please add anything ... also I would be interested to hear pros and cons for Discord.

text:
Thanks Leo, appreciate your feedback.

A couple of points to consider and I am glad you pointed to the Rust move to Zulip, a couple of notes from Rusts own guide on Zulip (<https://forge.rust-lang.org/platforms/zulip.html>).

> Zulip can be an unintuitive platform to get started with.
> Like Rust itself, Zulip is a bit special and reading the documentation before digging can be really helpful.
I'm also glad you brought up values, I agree that is extremely important.

The KERI community is a diverse one, we have people from _literally_ all across the world and all walks of life they're not just developers and as you noted:
> zulip is also much more accessible for developers
We have lawyers, ux designers, musicians, philanthropists, a wide range of "non-technical" (I dislike this term but it works for now) people who contribute and want to be part of this community.

Selecting a tool which would provide the easiest and broadest support to our diverse group is of extremely high value to me.
Migrating to something with a familiar interface, server/workspace channel structure would maintain accessibility for the whole community and maybe even a tool they already use, not an additional one.

I'd be incredibly sad to think an artist or product manager, felt they couldn't engage with the community because they did not feel "savvy" enough.

As others may point out, this could all be moot anyway, this was the first mention and we there are no concrete plans in the community.

text:
> I just don’t think we should sacrifice our core values
This statement seems a bit exaggerated. Using Discord wouldn’t require us to sacrifice our core values. We haven’t articulated any core values around data sharing and privacy just yet that conflict with what Discord does. And, really, we already live in a surveillance state. Not using Discord won’t stop large state actors from ingesting every piece of data they can get anyway, and the large data brokers from correlating all of that data.

> As a community we can have huge influence
I don’t think we’re in a place yet where we could benefit enough from the move to Zulip to justify the potential costs.

text:
Anonymity is not as big of a core value in this community as it is in other cryptography communities where zero knowledge proofs are king.
The alternative is something like chain-link confidentiality, which uses the law, rather than fancy cryptography, to protect the data interests and rights of people.

Maybe the KERI & ACDC community can get a custom contract with Discord that respects chain link confidentiality. Not sure how likely that is, though that would be a way to encode the core ethos and values of KERI & ACDC in our messaging tool of choice.

text:
I think <@U05DT8YPEG1> raised an interesting point on the value alignment between KERI/ACDC and SSI.

I cannot speak for others in the community about what they think the values of KERI/ACDC and the community are, but for me, KERI/ACDC represents something more foundational than SSI. One can use KERI/ACDC to build either SSI or non-SSI applications/ecosystems.

From the technical standpoint, the core value of KERI/ACDC is in “Authenticity”, that is, to build something with strong secure attribution. Other properties like privacy, confidentiality, and anonymity are important too, but they are not the top priority.

This is quite different from the core value of SSI which emphasizes self-sovereignty, control, and ownership of personal data for individuals.

However, the technical value may or may not reflect the values of members of the community. This might be a good philosophical discussion for the community.

root.text:
> I just don’t think we should sacrifice our core values
This statement seems a bit exaggerated. Using Discord wouldn’t require us to sacrifice our core values. We haven’t articulated any core values around data sharing and privacy just yet that conflict with what Discord does. And, really, we already live in a surveillance state. Not using Discord won’t stop large state actors from ingesting every piece of data they can get anyway, and the large data brokers from correlating all of that data.

> As a community we can have huge influence
I don’t think we’re in a place yet where we could benefit enough from the move to Zulip to justify the potential costs.

text:
I can share same view from perspective of Human Colossus that protocols behind KERI and ACDC address low level architecture of authenticity in general. We have many applications where those protocols have nothing to do with SSI. It does not mean that you cannot build SSI application but we cannot ignore the existing world which is not SSI driven and won't be for very long time.

In our case we leveraging properties of KERI to provide integrity (SAID) and authenticity (SCID)  to lower layers of dynamic data economy stack, You can read more about that in this blog post: <https://humancolossus.foundation/blog/accuratedata1> and in referenced in that blog post document about DDE <https://static1.squarespace.com/static/5ead4c8660689c348c80958e/t/62f2893465394d4b829661bc/1660062007339/HCF+DDE+Trust+Infrastructure+Stack+v1.0.0.pdf|Trust Infrastructure Stack>

text:
For those who are interested in bigger picture of the dynamic data economy, recommend recent publication from HCF: <https://arxiv.org/abs/2308.07280>
on Distributed Governance: a Principal-Agent Approach to Data Governance. Would love to hear your feedback!

elements.text: For those who are interested in bigger picture of the dynamic data economy, recommend recent publication from HCF:
on Distributed Governance: a Principal-Agent Approach to Data Governance. Would love to hear your feedback!

attachments.fallback: arXiv.org: Distributed Governance: a Principal-Agent Approach to Data Governance -- Part 1 Background & Core Definitions
attachments.text:
To address the need for regulating digital technologies without hampering
innovation or pre-digital transformation regulatory frameworks, we provide a
model to evolve Data governance toward Information governance and precise the
relation between these two terms. This model bridges digital and non-digital
information exchange. By considering the question of governed data usage
through the angle of the Principal-Agent problem, we build a distributed
governance model based on Autonomous Principals defined as entities capable of
choice, therefore capable of exercising a transactional sovereignty. Extending
the legal concept of the privacy sphere to a functional equivalent in the
digital space leads to the construction of a digital self to which rights and
accountability can be attached. Ecosystems, defined as communities of
autonomous principals bound by a legitimate authority, provide the basis of
interacting structures of increasing complexity endowed with a self-replicating
property that mirrors physical world governance systems. The model proposes a
governance concept for multi-stakeholder information systems operating across
jurisdictions. Using recent software engineering advances in decentralised
authentication and semantics, we provide a framework, Dynamic Data Economy to
deploy a distributed governance model embedding checks and balance between
human and technological governance. Domain specific governance models are left
for further publications. Similarly, the technical questions related to the
connection between a digital-self and its physical world controller (e.g
biometric binding) will be treated in upcoming publications.
attachments.title: Distributed Governance: a Principal-Agent Approach to Data Governance -- Part 1 Background & Core Definitions

text:
Hi, <@U04H17ZEX9R>. Believe it or not, I just noticed this now. Sorry to be 2 months late. Wow.

Yes, metadata stored *inside* the file is hashed along with content. But metadata stored *outside* the file (e.g., last mod date, permissions) is NOT hashed.

When SAID is embedded in filename, the SAID does *not* have to be recomputed when the filename changes. The filename is not input to the hash function. Rather, the regex for the filename that's stored inside the file is input to the hash -- and that regex doesn't change when the filename changes. For example, if the regex is `.*{said}\.docx`, then any filename containing the SAID and ending in docx is a valid filename, and nothing needs to be recomputed when the file is renamed.

Re. multi-OS: no, this metadata is not hashed and would not cause a problem.

text:
“However, we feel that achieving interoperability of VCs that are insecure, reliant on blockchain or web infrastructure, and not stress tested in production at scale is a hollow victory and premature; it is not meaningful interoperability. Security — in the form of proper key management — must come first, it cannot be bolted onto the current VC model just like it cannot be bolted onto the internet after the fact. There is no way around this.”

I consider the whole article a celebration of KERI-suite-powered credentials! Great to read.

text: I’m not aware of any smart contract platform currently with KERI support built in though what makes sense to me is something that is EUTXO style like the Cardano blockchain where the inputs are signed as an ACDC and the outputs are signed as an ACDC. The smart contract itself could use an in-memory keypair to sign things, sort of like SignifyTS does.

hmm, maybe I'm not creative enough but I don't quite understand.  Maybe it also has to do with the fuzziness of "smart contracts" and what that means.

Like if I had a (even for the simple case) finite state machine script I wanted to run and you and I were running it in a trust-less context where you didn't trust nodes under my control and I didn't necessarily trust nodes under your control.  How would that execute?

Like would we go to third party watchers/witnesses with extra functionality?  Or is that what judges and jurors are for in the future?  Or is there some other mechanism I'm just having trouble thinking of?

text:
The "Slack History" issue came up on the ACDC ToIP call today and I'd like to thank <@U02PA6UQ6BV> for continuing to work on this issue.

We took a brief Zoom chat vote which indicated that Discord was a preferred path forward for now for "general" discussion, GitHub Discussions were mentioned for long lived topics or in depth implementation discussions (ideally with an associated issue/PR) Kent mentioned Zulip again as a tool for development discussions as well, which I think falls into our future plans.

A migration to discord will allow us to keep the community together in a "social" manner and allow us to begin to deactivate Slack accounts in order to reduce the cost of a subscription to try retrieve old discussions.

I appreciate everyone's thoughtful comments and good intentions on the call and will post a link this week to a Discord server.

text:
reduce the cost of a subscription to try retrieve old discussions ->
It’s also a matter of principle. I am not amused with a software platform that holds back a vital part of its former service to lure you into a far too expensive subscription, based on an assessment of “active” users, who are for the most part not really active. If we can buy our way out for a few hundred US$ (estimated cost based on the current user base was 430 US$ a month (!) ) then I’ll do it right away. Buying our way out means: We need to get to see our old history and threads with explanations by Phil, Kevin, Sam and other experts to populate Q&As in KERISSE and Github Discussion items; either by hand or with API calls. The history we currently see is only 60 or 90 days old.

When the user base is small enough to have an acceptable exit amount to pay to Slack, I’ll proceed to buy a temporary subscription. And then pull all the history that’s still valuable out and structure it into KERISSE / Discussions, which are both Github-(Pages)based, so open source and no paywall traps (foreseen).

text: Discussion thread: how to efficiently watch witnesses

elements.text: Discussion thread: how to efficiently watch witnesses

text:
In Provenant's current command-line wallets, we run `kli local watch` every time we log in. This helps the different members of some of our multisig AIDs catch up if they've missed events since their last login. It works well.

However, I'd like an efficient way to do some more ambitious watching than this -- and that's what this thread is about.

Thing 1 that I'd like to do: `register a webhook with a witness so I can be called back any time ANY KEL/TEL changes`

Thing 2 that I'd like to do: `poll a witness efficiently for all changes in any KEL/TEL since timestamp or state hash X`

I am wondering if either of these things is already supported. If not, <@U024CJMG22J> or <@U024KC347B4>, do you think would the community accept a PR from Provenant adding either or both of these features?

Unlike the `kli local watch` command, the most convenient scope of both of these features would be "all the AIDs the witness services" rather than an enumerated subset of AIDs.

Regarding #1: I don't imagine that registering the webhook has to be exposed to the public over a web service endpoint; I'm rather imagining this as something configured internally by the owner/operator of a witness. Provenant would use it on its own witnesses, because it would make it very easy to discover that a credential has been issued or revoked, or a key has been rotated.

Regarding #2: I'm imagining this would happen over a web service endpoint exposed by the witness, and that it could potentially be called by the public (albeit with optional enforcement of some kind of proof of authorization). Provenant would love to call GLEIF's witnesses periodically over an API like this, making sure that we find out about any noteworthy changes rooted in those witnesses. With this feature, if a scope of "all the AIDs the witness services" is deemed too broad, it could still be useful for the smaller scope of an enumerated set of AIDs.

It is possible that this second feature is the logical inverse of the witness gossip feature that's been long imagined (pull vs. push), and that witness gossip could be implemented atop it (or at least with a lot of common code).

Provenant doesn't need these features in the next 6 weeks, but we probably do need them before the end of the year, so if it's something we need to work on, I'd love to be taught/pointed in the right direction and start the journey. If someone has already implemented part or all of this, or is in the process of doing so, so much the better.

text:
There is no support for callbacks coming out of witnesses.  That would be a net new feature.

There is a fairly extensive query API exposed from witnesses (as a matter of fact, `kli local watch` uses it) to support query for current state of an AID, current log of an AID and with parameters like, `sn=?` and `anchor={...}` which will live in the witness until that condition is met or until a timeout is reached.  All of these work using a KERI `qry` event and when satisfied, the witness sends back a `rpy` event, so they are asynchronous, not an HTTP interactive API.  Also, they all work on only one AID at a time.

If you want to see how it all works, you should start in `Kevery.processQuery` in `eventing.py` in KERIpy.  That is called from the parser when a `qry` event is streamed in.

elements.text: is there an example of a metadata ACDC disclosure as described here in one of the scripts?

attachments.text: An authentic chained data container (ACDC) is an IETF internet draft focused specification being incubated at the ToIP (Trust over IP) foundation . An ACDC is a variant of the W3C Verifiable Credential (VC) specification . The W3C VC specification depends on the W3C DID (Decentralized IDentifier) specification . A major use case for the ACDC specification is to provide GLEIF vLEIs (verifiable Legal Entity Identifiers) . GLEIF is the Global Legal Entity Identifier Foundation . ACDCs are dependent on a suite of related IETF focused standards associated with the KERI (Key Event Receipt Infrastructure) specification. These include CESR , SAID , PTEL , CESR-Proof , IPEX , did:keri , and OOBI . Some of the major distinguishing features of ACDCs include normative support for chaining, use of composable JSON Schema , multiple serialization formats, namely, JSON , CBOR , MGPK , and CESR , support for Ricardian contracts , support for chain-link confidentiality , a well defined security model derived from KERI , compact formats for resource constrained applications, simple partial disclosure mechanisms and simple selective disclosure mechanisms. ACDCs provision data using a synergy of provenance, protection, and performance.
attachments.title: Authentic Chained Data Containers (ACDC)

text: I’m in the process of migrating the history to Discord using Slackord. However there’s a bug in this software on MacOS and I’m waiting for the devs to repair it. Interestingly, I’ve seemed to have managed to save the whole history since 2020 in json files, without having to buy a membership. Nobody has been able to tell me about this option upfront, but anyways: I first want to see the result before I start cheering. Slackord is mission critical at the moment.

text:
I've spent some time studying. My unfamiliarity with the codebase is a handicap, but I made some progress.

Let me clarify why I want this.

Provenant imagines supporting high-speed signing for millions of brands. These brands will all have a multisig AID, and they will delegate signing authority to a single-sig AID that can be operated by automation at machine speed. Signing an SMS message or similar does not generate an ACDC and is not anchored to the KEL, because the signatures are only relevant for a short lifecycle (e.g., 10 seconds).

All of these brands will want to be able to revoke delegated signing authority with low latency (e.g., a few seconds of reaction time). This means that Provenant needs to know if delegated authority was changed on millions of AIDs, within a few seconds of when it happens. I don't believe it will be practical to monitor individual KELs and poll for changes.

The good news is, 99.9% of these brands should be using Provenant witnesses. If we configure our own witnesses to tell us when the KEL of an AID changes (the new feature I want, not callable over public web interface), we can then call the witness back and get an updated version of the KEL (existing witness feature), very soon after the change occurs.  Since most KELs are unlikely to change frequently, we will have the efficiency we need.

It seems to me that what I want might best be hooked up to KeyStateNoticer and WitnessInquisitor in some way. Am I in the right ballpark?

text:
fully agree, permanently delete a workspace is easier than to suspend it first (a few maintenance actions have to be executed in the latter case). It’s Sam who has to perform the permanent deletion.
The problem of permanent deletion is that we do have the text of all history, but not the vids / pcitures uploaded to historical conversations yet. We’re still waiting for a Third Party Tool to update and debug their Apple Mac tool for me to be able to look what they’ve got to do so. There’s also this open <https://github.com/WebOfTrust/WOT-terms/issues/65|issue>, where <@U024KC347B4> offered to use his MS Windows machine to perform the history scrape (that does not have the Slackord bug).
We’ll lose pcitures / vids if we delete the workspace permanently before we’ll get the attachments  to conversations out. It would be a choice to do so.

text:
From my research (using chatGPT):
To download images and videos from a Slack workspace, which are not included in the standard workspace history export, you can follow these steps:
1. Use Slack’s API: Slack’s API provides endpoints for accessing files uploaded to your workspace. You can use methods like `files.list` to retrieve a list of file URLs. This requires some programming knowledge and an understanding of working with APIs.
2. Manual Download: If there aren’t many files or if you’re looking for specific ones, you can manually download them. Go to the conversation or channel where the file was shared and click on the file to download it.
3. Third-party Tools: There are third-party tools and services available that can help you download all files from your Slack workspace. These tools usually integrate with Slack and automate the process of downloading files. Be sure to choose a reputable and secure service, as this involves sensitive data.
4. Request Slack Support: If you’re facing difficulties or if your workspace has a large number of files, consider contacting Slack support for assistance. They may be able to provide a solution tailored to your specific needs.
5. Automate with a Script: If you have programming skills, you can write a script using Slack’s API to automate the download process. This could be especially useful if there are a large number of files.
Even though I could go for option 2, I’m not interested to manually reconstruct it this way.
